{"uri": "8201543357", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "12:59:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T12:59:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T12:59:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9254902005195618, "url": "https://www.deccanchronicle.com/world/tense-france-goes-to-polls-as-far-right-scents-power-1308675", "title": "Tense France goes to polls as far-right scents power", "body": "Paris: Voting got underway in France's overseas territories on Saturday in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections, which could change the country's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nResidents of the tiny French archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, began casting their ballots in the first round of elections from 1000 GMT.\n\nThey will be followed by voters in France's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana. Voting will later start in territories in the Pacific and then in the Indian Ocean before it gets underway on the mainland on Sunday.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the lower house National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round a week later, on July 7.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices soaring, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally party has surged.\n\nMost polls show that National Rally is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for President Emmanuel Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X on Friday.\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine, by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nThe party's path to victory could be blocked if the left and centre-right join forces against the RN in the second round.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.", "source": {"uri": "deccanchronicle.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Deccan Chronicle"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8201570567", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "13:25:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T13:25:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T13:25:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9176470637321472, "url": "https://www.bssnews.net/international/197513", "title": "Tense France goes to polls as far-right scents power | International", "body": "PARIS, June 29, 2024 (BSS/AFP) - Voting got underway in France's overseas territories on Saturday in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections, which could change the country's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nResidents of the tiny French archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, began casting their ballots in the first round of elections from 1000 GMT.\n\nThey will be followed by voters in France's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana. Voting will later start in territories in the Pacific and then in the Indian Ocean before it gets underway on the mainland on Sunday.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the lower house National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round a week later, on July 7.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices soaring, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally party has surged.\n\nMost polls show that National Rally is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for President Emmanuel Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\n- 'No precedent' -\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\n- 'Victory is within grasp' -\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X on Friday.\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine, by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nThe party's path to victory could be blocked if the left and centre-right join forces against the RN in the second round.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.", "source": {"uri": "bssnews.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Bangladesh Sangbad Sangstha (BSS)"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8201570437", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "13:25:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T13:25:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T13:25:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9176470637321472, "url": "https://www.fox28spokane.com/tense-france-goes-to-polls-as-far-right-scents-power/", "title": "Tense France goes to polls as far-right scents power | FOX 28 Spokane", "body": "Voting got underway in France's overseas territories on Saturday in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections, which could change the country's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nResidents of the tiny French archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, began casting their ballots in the first round of elections from 1000 GMT.\n\nThey will be followed by voters in France's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana. Voting will later start in territories in the Pacific and then in the Indian Ocean before it gets underway on the mainland on Sunday.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the lower house National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round a week later, on July 7.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices soaring, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally party has surged.\n\nMost polls show that National Rally is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for President Emmanuel Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\n- 'No precedent' -\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\n- 'Victory is within grasp' -\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X on Friday.\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine, by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nThe party's path to victory could be blocked if the left and centre-right join forces against the RN in the second round.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.\n\nSome 49 million French are eligible to vote.\n\nare-fff-adc-as/db\n\nFOX28 Spokane\u00a9", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-405644288", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "09:32:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T09:32:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T09:30:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9137254953384399, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com.au/far-right-scents-power-tense-france-braces-snap-vote-1849041", "title": "Far Right Scents Power As Tense France Braces For Snap Vote", "body": "A divided France braced Saturday for high-stakes parliamentary elections that could see the anti-immigrant and eurosceptic party of Marine Le Pen sweep to power in a historic first.\n\nThe candidates ended their frantic three-week campaigns at midnight Friday, with political activity banned until the first round of voting on Sunday.\n\nOn Saturday, voting begins in France's overseas territories that span the globe, with residents of the tiny archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, casting their ballots from 1000 GMT.\n\nThey will be followed by voters in France's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana. Voting will later start in territories in the Pacific and then in the Indian Ocean before it gets underway on the mainland on Sunday.\n\nMost polls show that Le Pen's far-right National Rally (RN) is on course to win the largest number of seats in the 577-member National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for President Emmanuel Macron's centrist camp.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action ahead of the second round of voting on July 7, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nSome 49 million French are eligible to vote.\n\nBrice Teinturier, head of the Ipsos polling firm, said there were two tendancies coming out of the campaign.\n\n\"One is a dynamic of hope\" with left-wing and RN supporters believing that \"there can be a change\".\n\nBut Teinturier also highlighted \"the negative politicisation, the fear, the dread caused\" by the RN and the hard-left France Unbowed party which is part of the left-wing coalition.\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nSpeaking in Brussels late Thursday, Macron deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp collapsed during the campaign, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nSupport for the far right has surged, with analysts saying Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have paid off.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X on Friday, vowing to bolster purchasing power and \"curb insecurity and immigration\".\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and her 28-year-old lieutenant, party chief Jordan Bardella, have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine, by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nIf the far right obtains an absolute majority, Bardella could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nHis party's path to victory could be blocked if the left and centre-right join forces against the RN in the second round.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war\" in France.\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until {"uri": "2024-06-405812187", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "13:28:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T13:28:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T12:16:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9098039269447327, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/tense-france-goes-to-polls-as-far-right-scents-power/article_b5f68456-8f7e-59de-8a52-fc0660b4251f.html", "title": "Tense France goes to polls as far-right scents power", "body": "French President Emmanuel Macron has called snap parliamentary polls after the far-right National Rally party's victory in European elections\n\nVoting got underway in France's overseas territories on Saturday in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections, which could change the country's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nResidents of the tiny French archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, began casting their ballots in the first round of elections from 1000 GMT.\n\nThey will be followed by voters in France's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana. Voting will later start in territories in the Pacific and then in the Indian Ocean before it gets underway on the mainland on Sunday.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the lower house National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round a week later, on July 7.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices soaring, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally party has surged.\n\nMost polls show that National Rally is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for President Emmanuel Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\n- 'No precedent' -\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\n- 'Victory is within grasp' -\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X on Friday.\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine, by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nThe party's path to victory could be blocked if the left and centre-right join forces against the RN in the second round.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.\n\nSome 49 million French are eligible to vote.\n\nare-fff-adc-as/db\n\nMore from this section\n\nHow to Record Phone Calls on iPhone in 2024? - iCarefone Recorder iOS APP\n\nStart Your Engines and Join the Race: Help Create a Drug-Free World\n\nEnergyCAP Named Market Leader in the Summer 2024 Energy Management Software {"uri": "8201375576", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "10:21:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T10:21:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T10:21:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9098039269447327, "url": "https://www.malaymail.com/news/world/2024/06/29/far-right-scents-power-as-tense-france-braces-for-snap-vote/142111", "title": "Far-right scents power as tense France braces for snap vote", "body": "PARIS, June 29 -- A divided France braced Saturday for high-stakes parliamentary elections that could see the anti-immigrant and euro-sceptic party of Marine Le Pen sweep to power in a historic first.\n\nThe candidates ended their frantic three-week campaigns at midnight Friday, with political activity banned until the first round of voting on Sunday.\n\nOn Saturday, voting begins in France's overseas territories that span the globe, with residents of the tiny archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, casting their ballots from 1000 GMT.\n\nThey will be followed by voters in France's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana. Voting will later start in territories in the Pacific and then in the Indian Ocean before it gets underway on the mainland on Sunday.\n\nMost polls show that Le Pen's far-right National Rally (RN) is on course to win the largest number of seats in the 577-member National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 per cent of the vote, against 27.5-29 per cent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for President Emmanuel Macron's centrist camp.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action ahead of the second round of voting on July 7, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nBrice Teinturier, head of the Ipsos polling firm, said there were two tendancies coming out of the campaign.\n\n\"One is a dynamic of hope\" with left-wing and RN supporters believing that \"there can be a change\".\n\nBut Teinturier also highlighted \"the negative politicisation, the fear, the dread caused\" by the RN and the hard-left France Unbowed party which is part of the left-wing coalition.\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nSpeaking in Brussels late Thursday, Macron deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp collapsed during the campaign, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nSupport for the far right has surged, with analysts saying Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have paid off.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X on Friday, vowing to bolster purchasing power and \"curb insecurity and immigration\".\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and her 28-year-old lieutenant, party chief Jordan Bardella, have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine, by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nIf the far right obtains an absolute majority, Bardella could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nHis party's path to victory could be blocked if the left and centre-right join forces against the RN in the second round.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war\" in France.\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until {"uri": "2024-06-405811571", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "13:26:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T13:26:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T13:05:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://english.alarabiya.net/News/world/2024/06/29/tense-france-goes-to-polls-as-far-right-scents-power", "title": "Tense France goes to polls as far-right scents power", "body": "Voting got underway in France's overseas territories on Saturday in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections, which could change the country's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nResidents of the tiny French archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, began casting their ballots in the first round of elections from 1000 GMT.\n\nFor all the latest headlines follow our Google News channel online or via the app.\n\nThey will be followed by voters in France's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana. Voting will later start in territories in the Pacific and then in the Indian Ocean before it gets underway on the mainland on Sunday.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the lower house National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round a week later, on July 7.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices soaring, support for the anti-immigration and Eurosceptic National Rally party has surged.\n\nMost polls show that National Rally is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for President Emmanuel Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\n'No precedent'\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilize against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\n'Victory is within grasp'\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X on Friday.\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine, by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nThe party's path to victory could be blocked if the left and center-right join forces against the RN in the second round.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.\n\nFrance says extremely concerned by gravity of situation in Lebanon\n\nFrance appeals court upholds intl arrest warrant Voting will later start in territories in the Pacific and then in the Indian Ocean before it gets underway on the mainland on Sunday.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the lower house National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round a week later, on July 7.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices soaring, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally party has surged.\n\nMost polls show that National Rally is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for President Emmanuel Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\n- 'No precedent' -\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nMore from this section Toronto council passes renoviction bylaw to protect renters Severe storm forces popular Wall Township camp to close Thursday Joe Biden branded a 'dementia ridden man' as President prepares for 'completely live' leadership debate\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\n- 'Victory is within grasp' -\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X on Friday.\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine, by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nThe party's path to victory could be blocked if the left and centre-right join forces against the RN in the second round.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nHe has insisted he will serve {"uri": "2024-06-405679726", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "10:19:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T10:19:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T09:31:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "url": "https://arab.news/rfanz", "title": "Far right scents power as tense France braces for snap vote", "body": "On Saturday, voting begins in France's overseas territories that span the globe\n\nPARIS: A divided France braced Saturday for high-stakes parliamentary elections that could see the anti-immigrant and euroskeptic party of Marine Le Pen sweep to power in a historic first.\n\nThe candidates ended their frantic three-week campaigns at midnight Friday, with political activity banned until the first round of voting on Sunday.\n\nOn Saturday, voting begins in France's overseas territories that span the globe, with residents of the tiny archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, casting their ballots from 1000 GMT.\n\nThey will be followed by voters in France's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana. Voting will later start in territories in the Pacific and then in the Indian Ocean before it gets underway on the mainland on Sunday.\n\nMost polls show that Le Pen's far-right National Rally (RN) is on course to win the largest number of seats in the 577-member National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for President Emmanuel Macron's centrist camp.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action ahead of the second round of voting on July 7, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilize against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nSome 49 million French are eligible to vote.\n\nBrice Teinturier, head of the Ipsos polling firm, said there were two tendancies coming out of the campaign.\n\n\"One is a dynamic of hope\" with left-wing and RN supporters believing that \"there can be a change.\"\n\nBut Teinturier also highlighted \"the negative politicization, the fear, the dread caused\" by the RN and the hard-left France Unbowed party which is part of the left-wing coalition.\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nSpeaking in Brussels late Thursday, Macron deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism.\"\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp collapsed during the campaign, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nSupport for the far right has surged, with analysts saying Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have paid off.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X on Friday, vowing to bolster purchasing power and \"curb insecurity and immigration.\"\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and her 28-year-old lieutenant, party chief Jordan Bardella, have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine, by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nIf the far right obtains an absolute majority, Bardella could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nHis party's path to victory could be blocked if the left and center-right join forces against the RN in the second round.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war\" in France.\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/news/2024/0629/1457293-french-election/", "title": "Overseas French voters kick off high-stakes election", "body": "Voting is under way in France's overseas territories in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections, which could change the country's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nResidents of the tiny French archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, began casting their ballots in the first round of elections at 11am.\n\nThey will be followed by voters in France's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana.\n\nVoting will later start in territories in the Pacific and then in the Indian Ocean before it gets under way in France tomorrow.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the lower house National Assembly are a two-round process.\n\nThe shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round a week later on 7 July.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices soaring, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally party has surged.\n\nMost polls show that National Rally is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35% and 37% of the vote, against 27.5-29% for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21% for President Emmanuel Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Ms Le Pen's 28-year-old prot\u00e9g\u00e9 with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with President Macron.\n\nOn Monday, Mr Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources said.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Mr Rahman said.\n\nPresident Macron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4%, according to figures released yesterday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the {"uri": "8201841542", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "18:07:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T18:07:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T18:06:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/france-goes-polls-far-eyes-175816534.html", "title": "France goes to polls as far-right eyes historic win", "body": "Voting got underway in France's overseas territories Saturday in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections that could see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nResidents of the tiny French archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, were the first to cast their ballots in the first round of the election.\n\nFrance's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana also voted on Saturday.\n\nVoters in the Pacific territory of New Caledonia, hit by deadly riots last month, were due to go to polling stations from 10:00 pm Paris time (2000 GMT) before voting starts in mainland France Sunday.\n\nRussia's war against Ukraine is in its third year and energy and food prices are higher as a result. Support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nMost polls put the National Rally on course to win the largest number of seats in the 577-member National Assembly, parliament's lower house. But it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and the final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nThe shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round of voting on July 7.\n\n- Political 'impasse' -\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, tens thousands of people joined an LGBT Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far-right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the next course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes alike and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\n- 'Victory is within grasp' -\n\nMany observers have noted a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nThe French president apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp appears to have collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have paid off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X Friday.\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine, by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8201379623", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "10:24:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T10:24:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T10:24:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/far-right-scents-power-as-tense-france-braces-for-snap-vote/article_11ba2bfe-6c58-5d42-8e35-e96e9265ec0d.html", "title": "Far right scents power as tense France braces for snap vote", "body": "French people attend a campaign meeting with Raphael Glucksmann, a rising star of the left, in Rouen, northwestern France\n\nA divided France braced Saturday for high-stakes parliamentary elections that could see the anti-immigrant and eurosceptic party of Marine Le Pen sweep to power in a historic first.\n\nThe candidates ended their frantic three-week campaigns at midnight Friday, with political activity banned until the first round of voting on Sunday.\n\nOn Saturday, voting begins in France's overseas territories that span the globe, with residents of the tiny archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, casting their ballots from 1000 GMT.\n\nThey will be followed by voters in France's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana. Voting will later start in territories in the Pacific and then in the Indian Ocean before it gets underway on the mainland on Sunday.\n\nMost polls show that Le Pen's far-right National Rally (RN) is on course to win the largest number of seats in the 577-member National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for President Emmanuel Macron's centrist camp.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action ahead of the second round of voting on July 7, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nSome 49 million French are eligible to vote.\n\n- 'The fear, the dread' -\n\nBrice Teinturier, head of the Ipsos polling firm, said there were two tendancies coming out of the campaign.\n\n\"One is a dynamic of hope\" with left-wing and RN supporters believing that \"there can be a change\".\n\nBut Teinturier also highlighted \"the negative politicisation, the fear, the dread caused\" by the RN and the hard-left France Unbowed party which is part of the left-wing coalition.\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nSpeaking in Brussels late Thursday, Macron deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp collapsed during the campaign, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nSupport for the far right has surged, with analysts saying Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have paid off.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X on Friday, vowing to bolster purchasing power and \"curb insecurity and immigration\".\n\n- Power-sharing -\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and her 28-year-old lieutenant, party chief Jordan Bardella, have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine, by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nIf the far right obtains an absolute majority, Bardella could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nHis party's path to victory could be blocked if the left and centre-right join forces against the RN in the second round.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war\" in France.\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.\n\nare-fff-adc-as/db", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, "authors": [{"uri": "anna_smolchenko@ktbs.com", AFP\n\nThe candidates ended their frantic three-week campaigns at midnight Friday, with political activity banned until the first round of voting on Sunday.\n\nOn Saturday, voting begins in France's overseas territories that span the globe, with residents of the tiny archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, casting their ballots from 1000 GMT.\n\nThey will be followed by voters in France's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana. on course to win the largest number of seats in the 577-member National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for President Emmanuel Macron's centrist camp.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action ahead of the second round of voting on July 7, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, the French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilize against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nSome 49 million French are eligible to vote.\n\nBrice Teinturier, head of the Ipsos polling firm, said two tendencies were coming out of the campaign.\n\n\"One is a dynamic of hope\" with left-wing and RN supporters believing that \"there can be a change\".\n\nBut catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance, and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nSpeaking in Brussels late Thursday, Macron deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp collapsed during the campaign, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nSupport for the far right has surged, with analysts saying Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have paid off.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X on Friday, vowing to bolster purchasing power and \"curb insecurity and immigration\".\n\nUnder {"uri": "8202038307", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "22:26:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T22:26:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T22:26:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.voanews.com/a/france-goes-to-polls-as-far-right-eyes-historic-win-/7678288.html", "title": "France goes to polls as far right eyes historic win", "body": "Voting got underway in France's overseas territories Saturday in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections that could see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power for the first time.\n\nResidents of the tiny French archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, off the coast of Canada, were the first to cast their ballots in the first round of the election.\n\nFrance's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana also voted Saturday.\n\nAnd polling stations in the Pacific territory of New Caledonia, hit by deadly riots last month, opened at 10 p.m. Paris time (2000 GMT). Voting in mainland France starts Sunday.\n\nSupport for the anti-immigration and Eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nMost polls put the National Rally on course to win the largest number of seats in the 577-member National Assembly, parliament's lower house. But it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted, and the final opinion polls have given the RN between 35% and 37% of the vote, against 27.5-29% for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21% for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nCampaigning ended at Friday midnight. Candidates cannot speak publicly -- nor can any polls be published -- until Sunday evening when voting has finished.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nThe shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round of voting on July 7.\n\nPolitical 'impasse'\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, tens thousands of people joined an LGBTQ+ Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far-right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\nOnce the first-round results are in, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide how to respond to the situation, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes alike and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4%, according to figures released Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilize against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\n'Victory is within grasp'\n\nMany observers have noted a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism.\"\n\nThe French president apparently hoped to catch political opponents off-guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp appears to have collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's yearslong efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have paid off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration, and boost law and order.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X Friday.\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine, by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.", "source": {"uri": "voanews.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8202199350", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "02:55:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T02:55:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T02:54:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/world/france-votes-in-high-stakes-snap-polls-far-right-party-eyes-historic-victory-13787682.html", "title": "France votes in high stakes snap polls, far-right party eyes historic victory", "body": "Ballot boxes and electoral packages are seen at the 18th district city hall as local authorities prepare ballots and polling stations ready to welcome voters for the first round of the early French parliamentary elections, in Paris, France. Reuters\n\nFrench people vote on Sunday in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could alter France's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nPolling stations open across mainland France for the first round of elections at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories that span the globe cast ballots earlier in the weekend. Some 49 million French are eligible to vote.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round, a week later, on July 7.\n\nMost polls show that National Rally is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, RN party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nCalls to mobilise\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, thousands of people joined an LGBT Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far-right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\nSpike in hate speech\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp has collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on social media platform X on Friday.\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nHe has insisted he will serve the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-406160992", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "01:30:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T01:30:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T01:30:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com/france-votes-snap-polls-far-right-eyes-historic-win-3735483", "title": "France Votes In Snap Polls As Far-right Eyes Historic Win", "body": "French people vote on Sunday in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could alter France's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nPolling stations open across mainland France for the first round of elections at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories that span the globe cast ballots earlier in the weekend. Some 49 million French are eligible to vote.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round, a week later, on July 7.\n\nMost polls show that National Rally is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, RN party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, thousands of people joined an LGBT Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far-right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp has collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on social media platform X on Friday.\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.", "source": {"uri":
