{"uri": "8201383621", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "10:28:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T10:28:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T10:28:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/far-right-scents-power-as-tense-france-braces-for-snap-vote/article_fcd998c4-93bd-5609-9eb0-0d7c71bf0ffc.html", "title": "Far right scents power as tense France braces for snap vote", "body": "French people attend a campaign meeting with Raphael Glucksmann, a rising star of the left, in Rouen, northwestern France\n\nA divided France braced Saturday for high-stakes parliamentary elections that could see the anti-immigrant and eurosceptic party of Marine Le Pen sweep to power in a historic first.\n\nThe candidates ended their frantic three-week campaigns at midnight Friday, with political activity banned until the first round of voting on Sunday.\n\nOn Saturday, voting begins in France's overseas territories that span the globe, with residents of the tiny archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, casting their ballots from 1000 GMT.\n\nThey will be followed by voters in France's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana. Voting will later start in territories in the Pacific and then in the Indian Ocean before it gets underway on the mainland on Sunday.\n\nMost polls show that Le Pen's far-right National Rally (RN) is on course to win the largest number of seats in the 577-member National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for President Emmanuel Macron's centrist camp.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action ahead of the second round of voting on July 7, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nSome 49 million French are eligible to vote.\n\n- 'The fear, the dread' -\n\nBrice Teinturier, head of the Ipsos polling firm, said there were two tendancies coming out of the campaign.\n\nMore from this section Authorities: Suspect in custody following police pursuit in Tuckahoe Border Arrests Fall Over 40% Since Biden Suspended Asylum Processing US: Fan In Grimace Costume Chugs Beer During Rain Delay At Citi Field, New York 2\n\n\"One is a dynamic of hope\" with left-wing and RN supporters believing that \"there can be a change\".\n\nBut Teinturier also highlighted \"the negative politicisation, the fear, the dread caused\" by the RN and the hard-left France Unbowed party which is part of the left-wing coalition.\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nSpeaking in Brussels late Thursday, Macron deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp collapsed during the campaign, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nSupport for the far right has surged, with analysts saying Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have paid off.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X on Friday, vowing to bolster purchasing power and \"curb insecurity and immigration\".\n\n- Power-sharing -\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and her 28-year-old lieutenant, party chief Jordan Bardella, have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine, by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nIf the far right obtains an absolute majority, Bardella could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nHis party's path to victory could be blocked if the left and centre-right join forces against the RN in the second round.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war\" in France.\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.\n\nare-fff-adc-as/db", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8201355401", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "10:04:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T10:04:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T10:04:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.urdupoint.com/en/world/far-right-scents-power-as-tense-france-braces-1839397.html", "title": "Far Right Scents Power As Tense France Braces For Snap Vote - UrduPoint", "body": "Paris, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 29th Jun, 2024) A divided France braced Saturday for high-stakes parliamentary elections that could see the anti-immigrant and eurosceptic party of Marine Le Pen sweep to power in a historic first.\n\nThe candidates ended their frantic three-week campaigns at midnight Friday, with political activity banned until the first round of voting on Sunday.\n\nOn Saturday, voting begins in France's overseas territories that span the globe, with residents of the tiny archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, casting their ballots from 1000 GMT.\n\nThey will be followed by voters in France's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana. Voting will later start in territories in the Pacific and then in the Indian Ocean before it gets underway on the mainland on Sunday.\n\nMost polls show that Le Pen's far-right National Rally (RN) is on course to win the largest number of seats in the 577-member National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for President Emmanuel Macron's centrist camp.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nBrice Teinturier, head of the Ipsos polling firm, said there were two tendancies coming out of the campaign.\n\n\"One is a dynamic of hope\" with left-wing and RN supporters believing that \"there can be a change\".\n\nBut Teinturier also highlighted \"the negative politicisation, the fear, the dread caused\" by the RN and the hard-left France Unbowed party which is part of the left-wing coalition.\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nSpeaking in Brussels late Thursday, Macron deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp collapsed during the campaign, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nSupport for the far right has surged, with analysts saying Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have paid off.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X on Friday, vowing to bolster purchasing power and \"curb insecurity and immigration\".\n\nBut Le Pen and her 28-year-old lieutenant, party chief Jordan Bardella, have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine, by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nIf the far right obtains an absolute majority, Bardella could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nHis party's path to victory could be blocked if the left and centre-right join forces against the RN in the second round.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war\" in France.\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.", "source": {"uri": "urdupoint.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-06-406190500", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "03:04:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T03:04:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T01:32:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.rfi.fr/en/international-news/20240630-france-votes-in-snap-polls-as-far-right-eyes-historic-win", "title": "France votes in snap polls as far-right eyes historic win", "body": "Paris (AFP) - French people vote on Sunday in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could alter France's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nPolling stations open across mainland France for the first round of elections at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories that span the globe cast ballots earlier in the weekend. Some 49 million French are eligible to vote.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round, a week later, on July 7.\n\nMost polls show that National Rally is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, RN party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nCalls to mobilise\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, thousands of people joined an LGBT Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far-right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\nSpike in hate speech\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp has collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on social media platform X on Friday.\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8201856409", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "18:21:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T18:21:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T18:21:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/france-goes-to-polls-as-far-right-eyes-historic-win/article_fcd998c4-93bd-5609-9eb0-0d7c71bf0ffc.html", "title": "France goes to polls as far-right eyes historic win", "body": "Voting got underway in France's overseas territories Saturday in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections that could see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nResidents of the tiny French archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, were the first to cast their ballots in the first round of the election.\n\nFrance's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana also voted on Saturday.\n\nVoters in the Pacific territory of New Caledonia, hit by deadly riots last month, were due to go to polling stations from 10:00 pm Paris time (2000 GMT) before voting starts in mainland France Sunday.\n\nRussia's war against Ukraine is in its third year and energy and food prices are higher as a result. Support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nMost polls put the National Rally on course to win the largest number of seats in the 577-member National Assembly, parliament's lower house. But it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and the final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nThe shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round of voting on July 7.\n\n- Political 'impasse' -\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, tens thousands of people joined an LGBT Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far-right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the next course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMore from this section Water quality report finds high levels of bacteria in some East End waterways Adapted sailing: Pre-pandemic event returns to Hudson River Wednesday June Consumer Confidence Index Continues Rebound From April Low - TaiwanPlus News\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes alike and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\n- 'Victory is within grasp' -\n\nMany observers have noted a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nThe French president apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp appears to have collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have paid off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X Friday.\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine, by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.\n\nbur-as/jj", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", {"uri": "2024-06-405699102", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "10:47:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T10:47:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T09:25:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/far-right-scents-power-as-tense-france-braces-for-snap-vote/article_b5f68456-8f7e-59de-8a52-fc0660b4251f.html", "title": "Far right scents power as tense France braces for snap vote", "body": "French people attend a campaign meeting with Raphael Glucksmann, a rising star of the left, in Rouen, northwestern France\n\nA divided France braced Saturday for high-stakes parliamentary elections that could see the anti-immigrant and eurosceptic party of Marine Le Pen sweep to power in a historic first.\n\nThe candidates ended their frantic three-week campaigns at midnight Friday, with political activity banned until the first round of voting on Sunday.\n\nOn Saturday, voting begins in France's overseas territories that span the globe, with residents of the tiny archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, casting their ballots from 1000 GMT.\n\nThey will be followed by voters in France's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana. Voting will later start in territories in the Pacific and then in the Indian Ocean before it gets underway on the mainland on Sunday.\n\nMost polls show that Le Pen's far-right National Rally (RN) is on course to win the largest number of seats in the 577-member National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for President Emmanuel Macron's centrist camp.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action ahead of the second round of voting on July 7, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nSome 49 million French are eligible to vote.\n\n- 'The fear, the dread' -\n\nBrice Teinturier, head of the Ipsos polling firm, said there were two tendancies coming out of the campaign.\n\n\"One is a dynamic of hope\" with left-wing and RN supporters believing that \"there can be a change\".\n\nBut Teinturier also highlighted \"the negative politicisation, the fear, the dread caused\" by the RN and the hard-left France Unbowed party which is part of the left-wing coalition.\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nSpeaking in Brussels late Thursday, Macron deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp collapsed during the campaign, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nSupport for the far right has surged, with analysts saying Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have paid off.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X on Friday, vowing to bolster purchasing power and \"curb insecurity and immigration\".\n\n- Power-sharing -\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and her 28-year-old lieutenant, party chief Jordan Bardella, have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine, by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nIf the far right obtains an absolute majority, Bardella could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nHis party's path to victory could be blocked if the left and centre-right join forces against the RN in the second round.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war\" in France.\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.\n\nare-fff-adc-as/db\n\nMore from this section\n\nOld Vine Registry Marks One Year Anniversary and Announces Heritage Vine Hunt {"uri": "8202184908", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "02:31:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T02:31:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T02:31:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/france-votes-in-snap-polls-as-far-right-eyes-historic-win/article_ed0b7ed9-c3ed-524e-8e80-c29ae80eb9d4.html", "title": "France votes in snap polls as far-right eyes historic win", "body": "The polls could see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first\n\nFrench people vote on Sunday in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could alter France's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nPolling stations open across mainland France for the first round of elections at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories that span the globe cast ballots earlier in the weekend. Some 49 million French are eligible to vote.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round, a week later, on July 7.\n\nMost polls show that National Rally is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, RN party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\n- Calls to mobilise -\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nMore from this section Mosaics by priest accused of abuse must go, women say Police radio recording sheds light on OPP response at Walsh family home Clifton police seek 4 suspects wanted in hit-and-run crash that injured 72-year-old woman\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, thousands of people joined an LGBT Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far-right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\n- Spike in hate speech -\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp has collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on social media platform X on Friday.\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.\n\nbur-as/gv/mca", {"uri": "2024-06-406236272", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "04:48:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T04:48:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T02:04:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://arab.news/4w9f4", "title": "France votes in snap polls as far-right eyes historic win", "body": "Most polls show that National Rally is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly\n\nPARIS: French people vote on Sunday in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could alter France's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and euroskeptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nPolling stations open across mainland France for the first round of elections at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories that span the globe cast ballots earlier in the weekend. Some 49 million French are eligible to vote.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round, a week later, on July 7.\n\nMost polls show that National Rally is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, RN party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilize against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, thousands of people joined an LGBT Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far-right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism.\"\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp has collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on social media platform X on Friday.\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-406010299", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "18:51:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T18:51:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T17:58:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/france-goes-to-polls-as-far-right-eyes-historic-win/article_b5f68456-8f7e-59de-8a52-fc0660b4251f.html", "title": "France goes to polls as far-right eyes historic win", "body": "Voting got underway in France's overseas territories Saturday in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections that could see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nResidents of the tiny French archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, were the first to cast their ballots in the first round of the election.\n\nFrance's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana also voted on Saturday.\n\nVoters in the Pacific territory of New Caledonia, hit by deadly riots last month, were due to go to polling stations from 10:00 pm Paris time (2000 GMT) before voting starts in mainland France Sunday.\n\nRussia's war against Ukraine is in its third year and energy and food prices are higher as a result. Support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nMost polls put the National Rally on course to win the largest number of seats in the 577-member National Assembly, parliament's lower house. But it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and the final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nThe shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round of voting on July 7.\n\n- Political 'impasse' -\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, tens thousands of people joined an LGBT Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far-right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the next course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes alike and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\n- 'Victory is within grasp' -\n\nMany observers have noted a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nThe French president apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp appears to have collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have paid off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X Friday.\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine, by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.\n\nbur-as/jj\n\nMore from this section\n\n[Fixed!] {"uri": "8202163091", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "01:54:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T01:54:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T01:54:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/france-votes-in-snap-elections-as-le-pens-far-right-hopes-for-a-historic-win-101719711205426.html", "title": "France votes in snap elections as Le Pen's far-right hopes for a historic win", "body": "With Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nPolling stations open across mainland France for the first round of elections at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories that span the globe cast ballots earlier in the weekend. Some 49 million French are eligible to vote.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round, a week later, on July 7.\n\nMost polls show that National Rally is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, RN party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, thousands of people joined an LGBT Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far-right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp has collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on social media platform X on Friday.\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8202298344", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "05:10:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T05:10:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T05:10:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://www.zawya.com/en/world/uk-and-europe/france-votes-in-snap-polls-as-far-right-eyes-historic-win-jur19bu1", "title": "France votes in snap polls as far-right eyes historic win", "body": "With Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged\n\nFrench people vote on Sunday in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could alter France's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nPolling stations open across mainland France for the first round of elections at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories that span the globe cast ballots earlier in the weekend. Some 49 million French are eligible to vote.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round, a week later, on July 7.\n\nMost polls show that National Rally is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, RN party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\n- Calls to mobilise -\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, thousands of people joined an LGBT Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far-right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\n- Spike in hate speech -\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp has collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on social media platform X on Friday.\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-406189237", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "03:01:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T03:01:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T01:28:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/france-votes-in-snap-polls-as-far-right-eyes-historic-win/article_7b107c00-cc6b-57c9-87d9-dd523c06e104.html", "title": "France votes in snap polls as far-right eyes historic win", "body": "The polls could see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first\n\nFrench people vote on Sunday in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could alter France's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nPolling stations open across mainland France for the first round of elections at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories that span the globe cast ballots earlier in the weekend. Some 49 million French are eligible to vote.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round, a week later, on July 7.\n\nMost polls show that National Rally is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, RN party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\n- Calls to mobilise -\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, thousands of people joined an LGBT Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far-right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\n- Spike in hate speech -\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp has collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on social media platform X on Friday.\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.\n\nbur-as/gv/mca\n\nMore {"uri": "8202739939", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "12:23:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T12:23:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T12:23:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://kathmandupost.com/world/2024/06/30/france-votes-in-election-that-could-hand-power-to-far-right", "title": "France votes in election that could hand power to far right", "body": "President Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN).\n\nFrench voters headed to the polls on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls opened at 0600 GMT and will close at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, with an 1800 GMT finish in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" Le Pen said in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella, would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nA woman screamed \"It's shameful, it's shameful\" as Bardella arrived to cast his vote in Garches near Paris. \"They even invited the leftists,\" he said.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\nIn H\u00e9nin-Beaumont, a town in Le Pen's constituency in northern France where she may be re-elected in the first round, 67-year-old Denis Ledieu said people were suffering due to the long-term deindustrializaton of the region.\n\n\"So if the (RN) promises them things, then why not? They want to try it out, I think,\" he said.\n\nAcross France, early turnout figures were higher than in the 2022 legislative vote, at 25.9% by midday, compared with 18.43% two years ago, the interior ministry said.\n\n'Split vote favours RN'\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33%-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28%-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20%-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" Martigny said.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising Muslims and foreigners.", "source": {"uri": "kathmandupost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "kathmandupost.com"}, "authors": {"uri": "8202647484", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "10:56:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T10:56:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T10:56:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/france-begins-voting-in-pivotal-snap-polls-as-far-right-eyes-power-6002883", "title": "France Begins Voting In Pivotal Snap Polls As Far Right Eyes Power", "body": "President Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN).\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes\n\nParis, France:\n\nFrench voters began voting on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls opened at 0600 GMT and will close at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, with an 1800 GMT finish in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nAt a voting station in Sevres, on the outskirts of Paris, 70-year-old former company director Didier Delacroix said he had voted for Macron's alliance.\n\n\"Otherwise it'll be a complete mess,\" he said.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\n'Split Voters Favour RN'\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising Muslims and foreigners.\n\n(Except for the headline, {"uri": "8202114341", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "00:30:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T00:30:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T00:30:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/2475273/france-goes-to-polls-as-far-right-eyes-historic-win", "title": "France goes to polls as far-right eyes historic win", "body": "Voting got underway in France's overseas territories on Saturday in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections, which could change the country's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nResidents of the tiny French archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, began casting their ballots in the first round of elections from 1000 GMT.\n\nThey will be followed by voters in France's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana. Voting will later start in territories in the Pacific and then in the Indian Ocean before it gets underway on the mainland on Sunday.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the lower house National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round a week later, on July 7.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices soaring, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally party has surged.\n\nMost polls show that National Rally is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for President Emmanuel Macron's centrist camp. If the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy. \"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.", "source": {"uri": "tribune.com.pk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Express Tribune"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8202654825", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "11:04:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T11:04:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T11:03:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3001142-frances-far-right-surge-a-potential-shift-in-eu-dynamics", "title": "France's Far-Right Surge: A Potential Shift in EU Dynamics | Politics", "body": "French voters are partaking in a snap parliamentary election that might result in the country's first far-right government since World War Two. President Emmanuel Macron called this vote following a heavy defeat by Marine Le Pen's National Rally in recent European elections. An absolute majority win for RN could redefine France's role in the EU.\n\nFrench voters headed to the polls on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been. Polls opened at 0600 GMT and will close at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, with an 1800 GMT finish in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7. \"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" Le Pen said in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella, would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nA woman screamed \"It's shameful, it's shameful\" as Bardella arrived to cast his vote in Garches near Paris. \"They even invited the leftists,\" he said. If the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state. Bardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles. In H\u00e9nin-Beaumont, a town in Le Pen's constituency in northern France where she may be re-elected in the first round, 67-year-old Denis Ledieu said people were suffering due to the long-term deindustrializaton of the region.\n\n\"So if the (RN) promises them things, then why not? They want to try it out, I think,\" he said. Across France, early turnout figures were higher than in the 2022 legislative vote, at 25.9% by midday, compared with 18.43% two years ago, the interior ministry said.\n\n'SPLIT VOTE FAVOURS RN' Opinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33%-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28%-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20%-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon. How the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins. \"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" Martigny said.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time. Martigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments. But critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising Muslims and foreigners.
