{"uri": "8202274897", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "04:38:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T04:38:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T04:37:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.chinadailyasia.com/hk/article/586928", "title": "France to vote in election that could put far right in government", "body": "PARIS - French voters cast their ballots on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls open at 0600 GMT, closing at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, and at 1800 GMT in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nIf Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN) does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Le Pen's 28-year-old protege Jordan Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her protege, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nALSO READ: French election: National Rally seen winning 37% of popular vote\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the conflict in Ukraine. While the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\n'Split vote favors RN'\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36 percent of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31 percent and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23 percent\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36 percent of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31 percent and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23 percent.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nALSO READ: French PM refuses to 'promise the moon', clashes with far-right in debate\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5 percent of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favors the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nREAD MORE: France faces risk of violence due to snap election, {"uri": "8202724526", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "12:09:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T12:09:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T12:09:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/5897088", "title": "France votes in election that could hand power to far right | Taiwan News | Jun. 30, 2024 19:57", "body": "PARIS (Reuters) -- French voters headed to the polls on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls opened at 0600 GMT and will close at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, with an 1800 GMT finish in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" Le Pen said in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella, would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nA woman screamed \"It's shameful, it's shameful\" as Bardella arrived to cast his vote in Garches near Paris. \"They even invited the leftists,\" he said.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\nIn H\u00e9nin-Beaumont, a town in Le Pen's constituency in northern France where she may be re-elected in the first round, 67-year-old Denis Ledieu said people were suffering due to the long-term deindustrializaton of the region.\n\n\"So if the (RN) promises them things, then why not? They want to try it out, I think,\" he said.\n\nAcross France, early turnout figures were higher than in the 2022 legislative vote, at 25.9% by midday, compared with 18.43% two years ago, the interior ministry said.\n\n'SPLIT VOTE FAVOURS RN'\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33%-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28%-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20%-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" Martigny said.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover {"uri": "8202508585", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "08:50:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T08:50:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T08:49:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://e.vnexpress.net/news/world/france-goes-to-polls-as-far-right-eyes-historic-win-4764442.html", "title": "France goes to polls as far right eyes historic win - VnExpress International", "body": "Residents of the tiny French archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, off the coast of Canada, were the first to cast their ballots in the first round of the election.\n\nFrance's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana also voted on Saturday.\n\nAnd polling stations in the Pacific territory of New Caledonia, hit by deadly riots last month, opened at 10:00 pm Paris time (2000 GMT). Voting in mainland France starts on Sunday.\n\nSupport for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nMost polls put the National Rally on course to win the largest number of seats in the 577-member National Assembly, parliament's lower house. But it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and the final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nCampaigning ended at Friday midnight. Candidates cannot speak publicly -- nor can any polls be published -- until Sunday evening when voting has finished.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nThe shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round of voting on July 7.\n\nPolitical 'impasse'\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, tens thousands of people joined an LGBTQ Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far-right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\nOnce the first-round results are in, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide how to response to the situation, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes alike and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4%, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilize against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\n'Victory is within grasp'\n\nMany observers have noted a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nThe French president apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp appears to have collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have paid off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X Friday.\n\nUnder Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.\n\nBut Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine, by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.", "source": {"uri": "e.vnexpress.net", "dataType": Unravel the secrets right here.\n\nVoting got underway in France's overseas territories Saturday in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections that could see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.Residents of the tiny French archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, were the first to cast their ballots in the first round of the election.France's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana also voted on Saturday.Voters in the Pacific territory of New Caledonia, hit by deadly riots last month, were due to go to polling stations from 10:00 pm Paris time (2000 GMT) before voting starts in mainland France Sunday.Russia's war against Ukraine is in its third year and energy and food prices are higher as a result. Support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.Most polls put the National Rally on course to win the largest number of seats in the 577-member National Assembly, parliament's lower house. But it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.A high turnout is predicted and the final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.If the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.&nbsp;The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round of voting on July 7.- Political 'impasse' -&nbsp;Wielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.Separately, tens thousands of people joined an LGBT Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far-right.\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.On Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the next course of action, government sources told AFP.&nbsp;France is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy. &nbsp;\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.&nbsp;Macron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes alike and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.&nbsp;The Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.In an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.&nbsp;- 'Victory is within grasp' -&nbsp;Many observers have noted a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.&nbsp;Macron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".The French president apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.Support for Macron's centrist camp appears to have collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.Analysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have paid off. The party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Le Pen wrote on X Friday.Under Macron, France has been one of Ukraine's main Western backers since Russia invaded in 2022.But Le Pen and Bardella have said they would scale down French support for Ukraine, by ruling out the deployment of ground troops and long-range missiles.A defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left {"uri": "8202382764", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "06:49:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T06:49:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T06:48:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3000953-frances-political-crossroads-macron-vs-le-pen-in-historic-snap-election", "title": "France's Political Crossroads: Macron vs. Le Pen in Historic Snap Election | Politics", "body": "French voters are participating in the first round of a snap parliamentary election, potentially paving way for the first far-right government since WWII. Macron's centrist alliance faces a tough battle against Marine Le Pen's National Rally and a new left-wing coalition, with uncertain implications for France's future and EU relations.\n\nFrench voters began voting on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union. President Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls opened at 0600 GMT and will close at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, with an 1800 GMT finish in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected. However the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration. If the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nAt a voting station in Sevres, on the outskirts of Paris, 70-year-old former company director Didier Delacroix said he had voted for Macron's alliance. \"Otherwise it'll be a complete mess,\" he said.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state. Bardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles. 'SPLIT VOTE FAVOURS RN'\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23%. The New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique. Candidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" said Martigny. For decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse. Le Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising Muslims and foreigners. (Additional reporting by Paris bureau Writing by Estelle Shirbon Editing by Frances Kerry and Gareth Jones)\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a Voting will later start in territories in the Pacific and then in the Indian Ocean before it gets underway on the mainland on Sunday.\n\nMost polls show that Le Pen's far-right National Rally (RN) is on course to win the largest number of seats in the 577-member National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for President Emmanuel Macron's centrist camp.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action ahead of the second round of voting on July 7, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nBrice Teinturier, head of the Ipsos polling firm, said there were two tendancies coming out of the campaign.\n\n\"One is a dynamic of hope\" with left-wing and RN supporters believing that \"there can be a change\".\n\nBut Teinturier also highlighted \"the negative politicisation, the fear, the dread caused\" by the RN and the hard-left France Unbowed party which is part of the left-wing coalition.\n\nMacron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.", "source": {"uri": "enca.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "eNCAnews"}, {"uri": "8202418527", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "07:24:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T07:24:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T07:23:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/france-votes-in-snap-polls-as-far-right-eyes-power/article_5cd4bce2-4388-5812-ab95-38f5a98ea55e.html", "title": "France votes in snap polls as far right eyes power", "body": "Polls opened in France on Sunday for the first round of snap parliamentary elections which could see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nPolling stations opened across mainland France at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and will close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories that span the globe cast ballots earlier in the weekend. Some 49 million people are eligible to vote.\n\nCassandre Cazaux, a nurse who voted in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, where tensions remain high following last month's deadly riots, said the elections were \"decisive\".\n\n\"It should be well attended, but I don't know if everyone will play along and come out to vote,\" she said.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round on July 7.\n\nMost polls show the RN on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\n- Calls to mobilise -\n\nMacron's decision to call the snap vote after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, tens of thousands of people joined an LGBTQ Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\n- Spike in hate speech -\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nHe apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp has collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off.\n\nThe party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war\".\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.\n\nbur-as/imm", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, "authors": [{"uri": "anna_smolchenko@ktbs.com", "name": "Anna Smolchenko", "type": {"uri": "8202399932", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "07:07:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T07:07:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T07:06:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://cyprus-mail.com/2024/06/30/france-begins-voting-in-election-that-could-hand-power-to-far-right/", "title": "France begins voting in election that could hand power to far right", "body": "French voters began voting on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls opened at 0600 GMT and will close at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, with an 1800 GMT finish in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nAt a voting station in Sevres, on the outskirts of Paris, 70-year-old former company director Didier Delacroix said he had voted for Macron's alliance.\n\n\"Otherwise it'll be a complete mess,\" he said.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\n'SPLIT VOTE FAVOURS RN'\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising Muslims and foreigners.", "source": {"uri": "cyprus-mail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Cyprus Mail"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-06-406312927", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "07:10:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T07:10:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T07:05:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.ynetnews.com/article/hkcigkala", "title": "France begins voting in election that could hand power to far right", "body": "The far-right National Rally party has been courting Jews, but critics say this is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatizing Muslims and foreigners\n\nFrench voters are going to the polls Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War II, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls opened at 6 a.m. local time and will close at 4 p.m. in small towns and cities, with 6 p.m. finish in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her protege, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic program and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nAt a voting station in Sevres, on the outskirts of Paris, 70-year-old former company director Didier Delacroix said he had voted for Macron's alliance.\n\n\"Otherwise it'll be a complete mess,\" he said.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defense.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate center-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favors the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatizing Muslims and foreigners.", "source": {"uri": "ynetnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ynetnews"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8201758545", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "16:35:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T16:35:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T16:34:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.omanobserver.om/article/1155659/world/europe/tense-france-goes-to-polls-as-far-right-scents-power", "title": "Tense France goes to polls as far-right scents power", "body": "PARIS: Voting got underway in France's overseas territories on Saturday in high-stakes snap parliamentary elections, which could change the country's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nResidents of the tiny French archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, located off the coast of Canada, began casting their ballots in the first round of elections from 1000 GMT.\n\nThey will be followed by voters in France's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana. Voting will later start in territories in the Pacific and then in the Indian Ocean before it gets underway on the mainland on Sunday.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the lower house National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round a week later, on July 7.\n\nMost polls show that National Rally is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for President Emmanuel Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources said.\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's victory in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris. -- AFP", "source": {"uri": "omanobserver.om", {"uri": "8202398510", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "07:05:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T07:05:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T07:05:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13584579/France-begins-voting-election-hand-power-far-right.html", "title": "France begins voting in election that could hand power to far right", "body": "France holds first round of parliamentary election\n\n*\n\nAnti-immigrant, eurosceptic RN party ahead in polls\n\n*\n\nLeftist bloc in second, Macron's centrists in third\n\n*\n\nSecond round will take place on July 7\n\n*\n\nRN victory would disrupt policy towards EU, Ukraine\n\n(Updates with the start of voting, adds quote, paragraphs 7-8)\n\nBy Mimosa Spencer\n\nPARIS, June 30 (Reuters) - French voters began voting on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls opened at 0600 GMT and will close at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, with an 1800 GMT finish in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nAt a voting station in Sevres, on the outskirts of Paris, 70-year-old former company director Didier Delacroix said he had voted for Macron's alliance.\n\n\"Otherwise it'll be a complete mess,\" he said.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\n'SPLIT VOTE FAVOURS RN'\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising Muslims and foreigners. (Additional reporting by Paris bureau Writing by Estelle Shirbon Editing by Frances Kerry and Gareth Jones)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, {"uri": "8202427182", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "07:33:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T07:33:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T07:32:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/france-votes-snap-election-could-072642643.html", "title": "France votes in snap election which could see far right in Government", "body": "France is holding the first round of an early parliamentary election that could bring the country's first far-right government since Nazi occupation during the Second World War.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls opened at 6am and will close at 4pm in small towns and cities, with a 6pm finish in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round on July 7 are expected.\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36 per cent of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31 per cent and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23 per cent.However the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting next Sunday.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nAt a voting station in Sevres, on the outskirts of Paris, 70-year-old former company director Didier Delacroix said he had voted for Macron's alliance.\n\n\"Otherwise it'll be a complete mess,\" he said.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5 per cent of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls open at 0600 GMT, closing at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, and at 1800 GMT in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\nSplit vote facours RN\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover "Millions of French vote in snap polls as far right eyes power", "body": "French President Emmanuel Macron and his wife Brigitte vote in the first round of snap parliamentary elections in Le Touquet, northern France\n\nFrench voters turned out in large numbers on Sunday for the first round of high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could alter France's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the nation by calling snap polls after the far-right National Rally (RN) party's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic party has surged despite Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nThe two-round vote could put the far-right in power in France for the first time since the Nazi occupation in World War II.\n\nPresented with a crucial choice about France's future, many said they could not stay home, while political observers pointed to the highest voter turnout in decades.\n\nIn the southern city of Marseille, Nabil Agueni said he skipped the European elections but voted on Sunday.\n\n\"As long as we have a choice, it's better to go and vote\", the 40-year-old said.\n\n- 'Keep fighting' -\n\nIn the southwestern city of Bordeaux, Roxane Lebrun, 40, sounded worried.\n\n\"I don't recognise my country anymore,\" she said. \"We have to keep fighting for what we believe in and what we want for France.\"\n\nJulien Martin, a 38-year-old architect, added: \"These are not easy elections, the results are very uncertain, and the repercussions could be serious for society.\"\n\nMacron and his wife Brigitte cast their ballots in Le Touquet in northern France, with the 46-year-old president seen taking selfies and mingling with supporters.\n\nAs of noon, turnout in mainland France stood at 25.90 percent, an increase from the 18.43 percent recorded in legislative elections in 2022.\n\n\"This is the highest level since the 1981 legislative elections,\" Mathieu Gallard, research director at the Ipsos polling institute, said on X (formerly Twitter).\n\nAccording to most polls, the RN party is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if it will secure an outright majority.\n\n- Predictions of deadlock -\n\nFinal opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, compared to 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance, and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nMujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy, said turnout was key to the outcome of the election.\n\n\"The higher the turnout, the more candidates qualify,\" he said on X.\n\nHe said that the left-wing alliance and Macron's centrist camp would be able \"to make deals to withdraw worst-placed candidates and allow the others a free run against the far right candidate\" in the second round of voting.\n\nPolling stations opened across mainland France at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and will close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nPrime Minister Gabriel Attal was set to make a statement on Sunday evening, his team said.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nMany analysts say that France is facing a hung Assembly, which could lead to deadlock and political instability.\n\nThe shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round on July 7.\n\n- Spike in hate speech -\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories had cast ballots earlier in the weekend.\n\nElectors lined up to cast ballots in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, where tensions remain high following deadly riots there last month.\n\n\"It should be well attended, but I don't know if everyone will play along and come out to vote,\" said nurse Cassandre Cazaux.\n\nMacron's decision to call the snap vote plunged the country into political turmoil and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp tumbled during the campaign, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nbur-as/rox", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, "authors": [{"uri": "anna_smolchenko@ktbs.com", "name": "Anna {"uri": "8202413002", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "07:19:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T07:19:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T07:18:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/france-votes-in-snap-polls-as-far-right-eyes-power/article_ed0b7ed9-c3ed-524e-8e80-c29ae80eb9d4.html", "title": "France votes in snap polls as far right eyes power", "body": "Polls opened in France on Sunday for the first round of snap parliamentary elections which could see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nPolling stations opened across mainland France at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and will close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories that span the globe cast ballots earlier in the weekend. Some 49 million people are eligible to vote.\n\nCassandre Cazaux, a nurse who voted in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, where tensions remain high following last month's deadly riots, said the elections were \"decisive\".\n\n\"It should be well attended, but I don't know if everyone will play along and come out to vote,\" she said.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round on July 7.\n\nMost polls show the RN on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\n- Calls to mobilise -\n\nMacron's decision to call the snap vote after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nMore from this section The Real Deal: How to save money this Fourth of July Lindenhurst man sentenced to 7 to 21 years for crash that killed four Trump supporters celebrate, Biden faithful despair over US presidential debate\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, tens of thousands of people joined an LGBTQ Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\n- Spike in hate speech -\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nHe apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp has collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off.\n\nThe party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war\".\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.\n\nbur-as/imm", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": "anna_smolchenko@reformer.com", "name": {"uri": "2024-06-406299055", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "06:50:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T06:50:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T06:44:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/world/europe/2024/06/30/france-election-latest-news/", "title": "French voters head to polls for snap election that could usher in far-right government", "body": "Opinion polls show Marine Le Pen's National Rally has a comfortable lead of 33-36% of the popular vote\n\nFrench voters cast their ballots on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since the second World War, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her Eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a long-time pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls opened at 6am Irish time, and will close at 4pm in small towns and cities, and at 6pm in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7th.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her protege, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella, would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its postwar history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\n[ Macron shares Cameron's aloofness, invulnerability and catastrophic urge to call voters' bluff ]\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36 per cent of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31 per cent and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23 per cent.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, Eurosceptic, anti-Nato party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5 per cent of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" said Prof Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\n[ If Brexit Britain was an inflamed appendix, Eurosceptic France would be a malignant cancer ]\n\nProf Martigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing anti-Semitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN, had a history of overtly anti-Semitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising Muslims and foreigners. - France", "source": {"uri": "irishtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Irish Times"}, "authors": [],
