{"uri": "8202662846", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "11:11:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T11:11:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T11:10:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/france-votes-in-election-that-could-hand-power-to-far-right/82226209", "title": "France votes in election that could hand power to far right", "body": "PARIS (Reuters) -French voters headed to the polls on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls opened at 0600 GMT and will close at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, with an 1800 GMT finish in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" Le Pen said in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella, would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nA woman screamed \"It's shameful, it's shameful\" as Bardella arrived to cast his vote in Garches near Paris. \"They even invited the leftists,\" he said.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\nIn H\u00e9nin-Beaumont, a town in Le Pen's constituency in northern France where she may be re-elected in the first round, 67-year-old Denis Ledieu said people were suffering due to the long-term deindustrializaton of the region.\n\n\"So if the (RN) promises them things, then why not? They want to try it out, I think,\" he said.\n\nAcross France, early turnout figures were higher than in the 2022 legislative vote, at 25.9% by midday, compared with 18.43% two years ago, the interior ministry said.\n\n'SPLIT VOTE FAVOURS RN'\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33%-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28%-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20%-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" Martigny said.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising Muslims and foreigners.\n\n(Additional reporting by Ardee Napolitano and Janis Laizans in H\u00e9nin-Beaumont and Clotaire Achi, {"uri": "8201679999", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-29", "time": "15:14:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-29T15:14:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T15:14:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.thenationalnews.com/news/europe/2024/06/29/french-far-right-hopes-for-election-success-as-voting-starts/", "title": "French far right hopes for election success as voting starts", "body": "France's far right is hoping for a historic success in the parliamentary election as voting began on Saturday in the country's overseas territories.\n\nMarine Le Pen's anti-immigrant and eurosceptic party National Rally (RN) is leading, according to recent opinion polls.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron called the snap election earlier this month after his party suffered defeat in the European Parliament elections.\n\nThe move could see his presidency cut short three years before it was due to end if he loses.\n\nVoting for the new National Assembly began in France's overseas territories that span the globe, with residents of the tiny archipelago of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, off the coast of Canada, casting their ballots on Saturday.\n\nThey were being followed by voters in France's islands in the Caribbean and the South American territory of French Guiana. Voting in territories in the Pacific will be followed by those in the Indian Ocean before it gets under way on the mainland on Sunday.\n\nThe candidates ended their frantic three-week campaigns at midnight on Friday, with political activity banned until the first round of voting in France on Sunday.\n\nMost polls show that Ms Le Pen's RN party is on course to win the most seats in the 577-member National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\n\"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" Ms Le Pen wrote on X on Friday, vowing to bolster purchasing power and \"curb insecurity and immigration\".\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 per cent and 37 per cent of the vote, against 27.5 per cent to 29 per cent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance, and 20 per cent to 21 per cent for Mr Macron's centrist camp.\n\nOn Monday, Mr Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the course of action ahead of the second round of voting on July 7.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Mr Rahman said.\n\nSome 49 million French are eligible to vote.\n\nBrice Teinturier, head of the Ipsos polling firm, said there were two tendencies coming out of the campaign.\n\n\"One is a dynamic of hope\" with left-wing and RN supporters believing that \"there can be a change\".\n\nBut Mr Teinturier also highlighted \"the negative politicisation, the fear, the dread caused\" by the RN and the hard-left France Unbowed party which is part of the left-wing coalition.\n\nMr Macron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign.\n\nSpeaking in Brussels late on Thursday, Mr Macron deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nMr Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war\" in {"uri": "8202388989", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "06:56:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T06:56:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T06:55:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/france-begins-voting-in-election-that-could-hand-power-to-far-right/article_e638a8e2-804f-5293-bcd3-e51028db9214.html", "title": "France begins voting in election that could hand power to far right", "body": "By Mimosa Spencer\n\nPARIS (Reuters) -French voters began voting on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls opened at 0600 GMT and will close at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, with an 1800 GMT finish in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nAt a voting station in Sevres, on the outskirts of Paris, 70-year-old former company director Didier Delacroix said he had voted for Macron's alliance.\n\n\"Otherwise it'll be a complete mess,\" he said.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\n'SPLIT VOTE FAVOURS RN'\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising Muslims and foreigners.\n\n(Additional reporting by Paris bureauWriting by Estelle ShirbonEditing by Frances Kerry and Gareth Jones)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE GAZETTE", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Colorado Springs Gazette"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8202382755", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "06:49:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T06:49:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T06:48:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/france-votes-in-snap-polls-as-far-right-eyes-power-197937", "title": "France votes in snap polls as far right eyes power - World News", "body": "With Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nPolling stations opened across mainland France at 8:00 am (06:00 GMT) and will close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories that span the globe cast ballots earlier in the weekend. Some 49 million people are eligible to vote.\n\nCassandre Cazaux, a nurse who voted in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, where tensions remain high following last month's deadly riots, said the elections were \"decisive\".\n\n\"It should be well attended, but I don't know if everyone will play along and come out to vote,\" she said.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round on July 7.\n\nMost polls show the RN on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nMacron's decision to call the snap vote after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, tens of thousands of people joined an LGBTQ Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nHe apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp has collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off.\n\nThe party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war\".\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until {"uri": "8202873646", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "14:32:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T14:32:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T14:31:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.fox28spokane.com/millions-of-french-vote-in-snap-polls-as-far-right-eyes-power/", "title": "Millions of French vote in snap polls as far right eyes power | FOX 28 Spokane", "body": "French voters turned out in large numbers on Sunday for the first round of high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could alter France's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the nation by calling snap polls after the far-right National Rally (RN) party's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic party has surged despite Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nThe two-round vote could put the far-right in power in France for the first time since the Nazi occupation in World War II.\n\nPresented with a crucial choice about France's future, many said they could not stay home, while political observers pointed to the highest voter turnout in decades.\n\nIn the southern city of Marseille, Nabil Agueni said he skipped the European elections but voted on Sunday.\n\n\"As long as we have a choice, it's better to go and vote\", the 40-year-old said.\n\n- 'Keep fighting' -\n\nIn the southwestern city of Bordeaux, Roxane Lebrun, 40, sounded worried.\n\n\"I don't recognise my country anymore,\" she said. \"We have to keep fighting for what we believe in and what we want for France.\"\n\nJulien Martin, a 38-year-old architect, added: \"These are not easy elections, the results are very uncertain, and the repercussions could be serious for society.\"\n\nMacron and his wife Brigitte cast their ballots in Le Touquet in northern France, with the 46-year-old president seen taking selfies and mingling with supporters.\n\nAs of noon, turnout in mainland France stood at 25.90 percent, an increase from the 18.43 percent recorded in legislative elections in 2022.\n\n\"This is the highest level since the 1981 legislative elections,\" Mathieu Gallard, research director at the Ipsos polling institute, said on X (formerly Twitter).\n\nAccording to most polls, the RN party is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if it will secure an outright majority.\n\n- Predictions of deadlock -\n\nFinal opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, compared to 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance, and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nMujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy, said turnout was key to the outcome of the election.\n\n\"The higher the turnout, the more candidates qualify,\" he said on X.\n\nHe said that the left-wing alliance and Macron's centrist camp would be able \"to make deals to withdraw worst-placed candidates and allow the others a free run against the far right candidate\" in the second round of voting.\n\nPolling stations opened across mainland France at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and will close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nPrime Minister Gabriel Attal was set to make a statement on Sunday evening, his team said.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nMany analysts say that France is facing a hung Assembly, which could lead to deadlock and political instability.\n\nThe shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round on July 7.\n\n- Spike in hate speech -\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories had cast ballots earlier in the weekend.\n\nElectors lined up to cast ballots in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, where tensions remain high following deadly riots there last month.\n\n\"It should be well attended, but I don't know if everyone will play along and come out to vote,\" said nurse Cassandre Cazaux.\n\nMacron's decision to call the snap vote plunged the country into political turmoil and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp tumbled during the campaign, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nbur-as/rox\n\nFOX28 Spokane\u00a9", "source": {"uri": "fox28spokane.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX 28 Spokane"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8202264272", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "04:23:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T04:23:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T04:23:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://arynews.tv/france-to-vote-in-election-that-could-put-far-right-in-government/", "title": "France to vote in election that could put far right in government", "body": "Reuters is an international news organisation owned by Thomson Reuters\n\nVoters in France cast their ballots on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls open at 0600 GMT, closing at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, and at 1800 GMT in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nRead more: France arrests 8 in New Caledonia including independence leader\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising Muslims and foreigners.", "source": {"uri": "arynews.tv", "dataType": "news", "title": "ARY NEWS"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-406184768", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "02:47:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T02:47:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T02:43:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/france-vote-election-government-9423699/", "title": "France to vote in election that could put far right in government | World News - The Indian Express", "body": "The couple was greeted with loud cheers as its convoy drove into the grand temple grounds on Saturday evening and went on to perform puja guided by the priests.\n\nFrench voters cast their ballots on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls open at 0600 GMT, closing at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, and at 1800 GMT in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nExplained | Will France's snap elections spark the next euro crisis?\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nAlso in Explained | How France's snap legislative elections are shaping up\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\n'SPLIT VOTE FAVOURS RN'\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\nDon't Miss | France elections: What is cohabitation?\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising Muslims and foreigners.", "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Indian Express"}, "authors": {"uri": "8202844486", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "14:03:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T14:03:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T14:03:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/international/france-votes-crucial-polls-far-right-eyes-power", "title": "France votes in crucial polls as far right eyes power", "body": "FRENCH people voted on Sunday (Jun 30) in the first round of high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could alter France's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the nation by calling snap polls after the far-right National Rally (RN) party's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and euro-sceptic party has surged despite Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nThe two-round vote could put the far-right in power in France for the first time since the Nazi occupation in World War II.\n\nPolling stations opened across mainland France at 8 am (6 am GMT) and will close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nMany voters said they were concerned about the future.\n\n\"I don't recognise my country anymore,\" Roxane Lebrun, 40, said in the southwestern city of Bordeaux.\n\n\"We have to keep fighting for what we believe in and what we want for France.\"\n\nJulien Martin, a 38-year-old architect, added: \"These are not easy elections, the results are very uncertain, and the repercussions could be serious for society.\"\n\nMacron and his wife Brigitte cast their ballots in Le Touquet in northern France.\n\nOn Monday, the French president plans to convene a government meeting to decide the next course of action, sources have told AFP.\n\nMost polls show the RN party on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house - although it remains unclear if it will secure an outright majority.\n\nFinal opinion polls have given the RN between 35 and 37 per cent of the vote - against 27.5-29 per cent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance, and 20-21 per cent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nMany analysts say that France is facing a hung Assembly, which could lead to deadlock and political instability.\n\nAs of noon, turnout in mainland France stood at 25.90 per cent, an increase from the 18.43 per cent recorded in legislative elections in 2022.\n\nThe shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round on Jul 7.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories had cast ballots earlier in the weekend.\n\nElectors lined up to cast ballots in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, where tensions remain high following deadly riots there last month.\n\n\"It should be well attended, but I don't know if everyone will play along and come out to vote,\" said nurse Cassandre Cazaux.\n\nFormer president Nicolas Sarkozy, Greens party leader Marine Tondelier and former prime minister and Macron ally Edouard Philippe were among the first high-profile politicians to vote.\n\nPhilippe, the mayor of Le Havre in northern France who has made little effort to hide his ambitions for the presidency, was seen smiling and chatting to locals.\n\nMacron's decision to call the snap vote plunged the country into political turmoil and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 per cent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nMore than 100,000 joined an LGBTQ Pride march in Paris on Saturday, with some carrying placards targeting the far right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nHe apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp appears to have collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off.\n\nThe party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order. Spokane", "body": "French people voted on Sunday in the first round of high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could alter France's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the nation by calling snap polls after the far-right National Rally (RN) party's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic party has surged despite Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nThe two-round vote could put the far-right in power in France for the first time since the Nazi occupation in World War II.\n\nPolling stations opened across mainland France at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and will close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nMany voters said they were concerned about the future.\n\n\"I don't recognise my country anymore,\" Roxane Lebrun, 40, said in the southwestern city of Bordeaux.\n\n\"We have to keep fighting for what we believe in and what we want for France.\"\n\nJulien Martin, a 38-year-old architect, added: \"These are not easy elections, the results are very uncertain, and the repercussions could be serious for society.\"\n\nMacron and his wife Brigitte cast their ballots in Le Touquet in northern France.\n\nOn Monday, the French president plans to convene a government meeting to decide the next course of action, sources have told AFP.\n\nMost polls show the RN party on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house -- although it remains unclear if it will secure an outright majority.\n\nFinal opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote -- against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance, and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nMany analysts say that France is facing a hung Assembly, which could lead to deadlock and political instability.\n\n- 'Fight against hatred' -\n\nAs of noon, turnout in mainland France stood at 25.90 percent, an increase from the 18.43 percent recorded in legislative elections in 2022.\n\nThe shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round on July 7.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories had cast ballots earlier in the weekend.\n\nElectors lined up to cast ballots in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, where tensions remain high following deadly riots there last month.\n\n\"It should be well attended, but I don't know if everyone will play along and come out to vote,\" said nurse Cassandre Cazaux.\n\nFormer president Nicolas Sarkozy, Greens party leader Marine Tondelier and former prime minister and Macron ally Edouard Philippe were among the first high-profile politicians to vote.\n\nPhilippe, the mayor of Le Havre in northern France who has made little effort to hide his ambitions for the presidency, was seen smiling and chatting to locals.\n\nMacron's decision to call the snap vote plunged the country into political turmoil and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nMore than 100,000 joined an LGBTQ Pride march in Paris on Saturday, with some carrying placards targeting the far right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\n- Spike in hate speech -\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nHe apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp appears to have collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off.\n\nThe party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\nbur-as/rox\n\nFOX28 in crucial polls as far right eyes power", "body": "Macron's decision to call the vote plunged France into political turmoil and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy\n\nFrench people voted on Sunday in the first round of high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could alter France's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the nation by calling snap polls after the far-right National Rally (RN) party's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic party has surged despite Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nThe two-round vote could put the far-right in power in France for the first time since the Nazi occupation in World War II.\n\nPolling stations opened across mainland France at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and will close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nMany voters said they were concerned about the future.\n\n\"I don't recognise my country anymore,\" Roxane Lebrun, 40, said in the southwestern city of Bordeaux.\n\n\"We have to keep fighting for what we believe in and what we want for France.\"\n\nJulien Martin, a 38-year-old architect, added: \"These are not easy elections, the results are very uncertain, and the repercussions could be serious for society.\"\n\nMacron and his wife Brigitte cast their ballots in Le Touquet in northern France.\n\nOn Monday, the French president plans to convene a government meeting to decide the next course of action, sources have told AFP.\n\nMost polls show the RN party on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house -- although it remains unclear if it will secure an outright majority.\n\nFinal opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote -- against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance, and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nMany analysts say that France is facing a hung Assembly, which could lead to deadlock and political instability.\n\n- 'Fight against hatred' -\n\nAs of noon, turnout in mainland France stood at 25.90 percent, an increase from the 18.43 percent recorded in legislative elections in 2022.\n\nThe shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round on July 7.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories had cast ballots earlier in the weekend.\n\nElectors lined up to cast ballots in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, where tensions remain high following deadly riots there last month.\n\n\"It should be well attended, but I don't know if everyone will play along and come out to vote,\" said nurse Cassandre Cazaux.\n\nFormer president into political turmoil and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, Hallin-Mallet.\n\n- Spike in hate speech -\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp appears to have collapsed, while {"uri": "8202305551", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "05:20:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T05:20:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T05:19:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.wionews.com/world/france-elections-voters-to-cast-ballots-in-snap-polls-as-far-right-seeks-historic-win-736445", "title": "France elections: Voters cast ballots in snap polls as far right seeks historic win", "body": "France snap polls: Earlier this month, French President Emmanuel Macron stunned the nation when he called for a snap poll after his centrist alliance lost against Marine Le Pen's far-right National Rally (RN) in the European elections.\n\nVoters in France headed to the polls on Sunday (Jun 30) to cast their ballots in the first round of the high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two.\n\nThe polling stations across mainland France will open at 8:00 am (local time) and close 12 hours later. The polls will be closed earlier in small towns and later in the bigger cities.\n\nSubsequently, projections which usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy, will be released. However, France's electoral system can make it difficult to predict the distribution of seats that each party may secure in the 577-seat National Assembly, parliament's lower house.\n\nAlso Read | Nigeria: At least 18 killed after string of suspected suicide bomb attacks\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories which span across the world cast their ballots earlier in the weekend. The final results will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\nEarlier this month, French President Emmanuel Macron stunned the nation when he called for a snap poll after his centrist alliance lost against Marine Le Pen's far-right National Rally (RN) in the European elections.\n\nLe Pen's eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party has been operating on the sidelines for years but now has a good chance of winning.\n\nThree major political blocs are competing in this election - Le Pen's RN, Macron's centrist alliance, and the New Popular Front coalition that includes centre-left, greens and hard-left parties.\n\nOpinion polls show that RN has a chance of winning an absolute majority or at least 289 out of the 577 seats in the National Assembly.\n\nA report by AFP citing the final opinion poll ahead of the election gave RN between 35 per cent and 37 per cent of the vote, followed by 27.5-29 per cent for the recently formed New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 per cent for Macron's party.\n\nFrance also witnessed massive demonstrations after Macron's announcement as people protested against both the far right and the French president's decision. A high turnout is expected in this election.\n\nThe outcome of this election is important as despite Macron's presidency which will continue until 2027, the National Assembly is the more powerful of France's two houses of parliament.\n\nAlso Read | UN says five bombs planted by ISIS years ago found hidden in Iraq's Al-Nuri mosque\n\nTherefore, if RN does win an absolute majority, it would not only weaken Macron's presidency but also French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in an interview last week, and predicted that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister.\n\nThe RN has sought to spend more on the French economy and reduce immigration. Additionally, Bardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues.\n\n(With inputs from agencies)", "source": {"uri": "wionews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WION"}, Some 49 million people are eligible to vote.\n\nCassandre Cazaux, a nurse who voted in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, where tensions remain high following last month's deadly riots, said the elections were \"decisive\".\n\n\"It should be well attended, but I don't know if everyone will play along and come out to vote,\" she said.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round on July 7.\n\nMost polls show the RN on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 per cent and 37 per cent of the vote, against 27.5-29 per cent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 per cent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nCalls to mobilise\n\nMacron's decision to call the snap vote after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 per cent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right. \"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp has collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off.\n\nThe party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war\".\n\nHe has insisted he will {"uri": "8202875500", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "14:34:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T14:34:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T14:33:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3001317-french-snap-election-potential-shift-to-far-right-government", "title": "French Snap Election: Potential Shift to Far-Right Government | Politics", "body": "French voters participated in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that may result in the country's first far-right government since World War Two. President Macron called for the vote following his centrist alliance's defeat by Marine Le Pen's National Rally. High voter turnout reflected the electorate's engagement in the ongoing political crisis.\n\nFrench voters flocked to the polls on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union. President Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls opened at 0600 GMT and will close at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, with an 1800 GMT finish in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected. Participation was high, underlining how France's rumbling political crisis has energized the electorate. By midday, turnout was at 25.9%, compared with 18.43% two years ago - the highest comparable turnout figures since the 1981 legislative vote, Ipsos France's research director Mathieu Gallard said.\n\nFrance's electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of the second round of voting on July 7. \"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" Le Pen said in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella, would be prime minister.\n\nShe has sought to detoxify a party known for racism and antisemitism, a tactic that has worked amid voter anger at Macron, the high cost of living and growing concerns over immigration. In H\u00e9nin-Beaumont, a town in Le Pen's constituency in northern France where she may be re-elected in the first round, 67-year-old Denis Ledieu said people were suffering due to the long-term deindustrializaton of the region.\n\n\"So if the (RN) promises them things, then why not? They want to try it out, I think,\" he said. In Garches, a small town near Paris, a woman screamed \"It's shameful, it's shameful\" as Bardella arrived to cast his vote.\n\n\"They even invited the leftists,\" he said. On the other side of Paris, in the town of Meaux, 51-year-old Myl\u00e8ne Diop said she had voted for the New Popular Front, a hastily assembled left-wing coalition polling in second. She said it was \"the most important election\" of her life.\n\n\"The RN is at the gates of power and you see the aggressiveness of people and the racist speech that has been unleashed,\" she said. If the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state. Bardella says he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of its contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles. 'SPLIT VOTE FAVOURS RN'\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33%-36% of the popular vote, with the New Popular Front in second place on 28%-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20%-23%. The New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique. Candidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" Martigny said. For decades, as the RN steadily gained popularity, voters and parties joined forces to block it from winning power, but that may not hold true this time. (Additional reporting by Ardee Napolitano and Janis Laizans in H\u00e9nin-Beaumont and Clotaire Achi, Imad Creidi, Lucien Libert in Paris; Writing by Estelle Shirbon and Gabriel Stargardter; Editing by Frances Kerry, Gareth Jones and Andrew Heavens)\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", {"uri": "2024-06-406380846", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "08:55:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T08:55:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T06:24:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/france-votes-in-snap-polls-as-far-right-eyes-power/article_7b107c00-cc6b-57c9-87d9-dd523c06e104.html", "title": "France votes in snap polls as far right eyes power", "body": "Polls opened in France on Sunday for the first round of snap parliamentary elections which could see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nPolling stations opened across mainland France at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and will close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories that span the globe cast ballots earlier in the weekend. Some 49 million people are eligible to vote.\n\nCassandre Cazaux, a nurse who voted in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, where tensions remain high following last month's deadly riots, said the elections were \"decisive\".\n\n\"It should be well attended, but I don't know if everyone will play along and come out to vote,\" she said.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round on July 7.\n\nMost polls show the RN on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\n- Calls to mobilise -\n\nMacron's decision to call the snap vote after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, tens of thousands of people joined an LGBTQ Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\n- Spike in hate speech -\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nHe apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp has collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off.\n\nThe party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war\".\n\nHe has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, no matter which party wins.\n\nbur-as/imm\n\nMore from this section\n\nOld Vine Registry Marks One Year Anniversary and Announces Heritage Vine Hunt Contest\n\nEnergyCAP Named Market Leader in {"uri": "8202196615", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "02:52:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T02:52:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T02:51:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://bdnews24.com/world/europe/ebb9e9ce319b", "title": "France to vote in election that could put far right in government", "body": "People walk past campaign posters on election boards ahead of the June 30 and July 7 French legislatives elections, in Quiberon, western France, June 20, 2024. REUTERS\n\nFrench voters cast their ballots on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls open at 0600 GMT, closing at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, and at 1800 GMT in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising Muslims and foreigners.", "source": {"uri": "bdnews24.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "bdnews24.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8202698668", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "11:46:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T11:46:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T11:46:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.news24.com/news24/world/news/the-repercussions-could-be-serious-france-votes-in-pivotal-snap-polls-as-far-right-eyes-power-20240630", "title": "'The repercussions could be serious': France votes in pivotal snap polls as far right eyes power | News24", "body": "Paris - French people voted on Sunday in the first round of high-stakes snap parliamentary elections, which could see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nREAD | France begins frenetic campaign after Macron poll gamble\n\nThe vote could put the far-right in power in France for the first time since the Nazi occupation in World War II.\n\nPolling stations opened across mainland France at 08:00 (06:00 GMT) and will close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories that span the globe cast ballots earlier in the weekend. Some 49 million people are eligible to vote.\n\n\"These are not easy elections, the results are very uncertain, and the repercussions could be serious for society,\" said Julien Martin, a 38-year-old architect in the southwestern city of Bordeaux.\n\nVoters lined up to cast their ballots in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, where tensions remain high following last month's deadly riots.\n\nThe vote is \"decisive\", said Cassandre Cazaux, a nurse.\n\nCazaux added:\n\nBy midday local time, turnout in the archipelago, which is located between Australia and Fiji, stood at 32.4%, compared to 13.06% recorded during the 2022 legislative polls.\n\nFormer president Nicolas Sarkozy, Greens party leader Marine Tondelier, and former prime minister and Macron ally Edouard Philippe were among the first high-profile politicians to vote.\n\nPhilippe, the mayor of Le Havre in northern France who has made little effort to hide his ambitions for the presidency, was seen smiling and chatting to locals on Sunday morning.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round on 7 July.\n\nMost polls show the RN on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nFinal opinion polls have given the RN between 35% and 37% of the vote, against 27.5-29% for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21% for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nREAD: Maher Mezahi | French fascism casts shadow over Euros\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old proteg\u00e9 with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nMany analysts say that France is facing a hung Assembly, which could lead to deadlock and political instability.\n\n'Fight against hatred'\n\nMacron's decision to call the snap vote after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4%, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\nIt said:\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, more than 100 000 joined an LGBTQ Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\nSpike in hate speech\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nHe apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nREAD | Protests in Paris, Lyon, after French boys charged with rape of 12-year-old Jewish girl\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp has collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off.\n\nThe party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could
