{"uri": "8202858428", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "14:17:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T14:17:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T14:16:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/millions-of-french-vote-in-snap-polls-as-far-right-eyes-power/article_ed0b7ed9-c3ed-524e-8e80-c29ae80eb9d4.html", "title": "Millions of French vote in snap polls as far right eyes power", "body": "French voters turned out in large numbers on Sunday for the first round of high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could alter France's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the nation by calling snap polls after the far-right National Rally (RN) party's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic party has surged despite Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nThe two-round vote could put the far-right in power in France for the first time since the Nazi occupation in World War II.\n\nPresented with a crucial choice about France's future, many said they could not stay home, while political observers pointed to the highest voter turnout in decades.\n\nIn the southern city of Marseille, Nabil Agueni said he skipped the European elections but voted on Sunday.\n\n\"As long as we have a choice, it's better to go and vote\", the 40-year-old said.\n\n- 'Keep fighting' -\n\nIn the southwestern city of Bordeaux, Roxane Lebrun, 40, sounded worried.\n\n\"I don't recognise my country anymore,\" she said. \"We have to keep fighting for what we believe in and what we want for France.\"\n\nJulien Martin, a 38-year-old architect, added: \"These are not easy elections, the results are very uncertain, and the repercussions could be serious for society.\"\n\nMacron and his wife Brigitte cast their ballots in Le Touquet in northern France, with the 46-year-old president seen taking selfies and mingling with supporters.\n\nAs of noon, turnout in mainland France stood at 25.90 percent, an increase from the 18.43 percent recorded in legislative elections in 2022.\n\n\"This is the highest level since the 1981 legislative elections,\" Mathieu Gallard, research director at the Ipsos polling institute, said on X (formerly Twitter).\n\nAccording to most polls, the RN party is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if it will secure an outright majority.\n\n- Predictions of deadlock -\n\nFinal opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, compared to 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance, and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nMujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy, said turnout was key to the outcome of the election.\n\n\"The higher the turnout, the more candidates qualify,\" he said on X.\n\nHe said that the left-wing alliance and Macron's centrist camp would be able \"to make deals to withdraw worst-placed candidates and allow the others a free run against the far right candidate\" in the second round of voting.\n\nMore from this section Sharks take teen star Celebrini with top pick in NHL Draft STORM WATCH: Hot and humid conditions in Brooklyn; tracking afternoon storms Greater scrutiny urged as Manitoba trucking firms increasingly look outside Canada for drivers\n\nPolling stations opened across mainland France at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and will close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nPrime Minister Gabriel Attal was set to make a statement on Sunday evening, his team said.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nMany analysts say that France is facing a hung Assembly, which could lead to deadlock and political instability.\n\nThe shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round on July 7.\n\n- Spike in hate speech -\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories had cast ballots earlier in the weekend.\n\nElectors lined up to cast ballots in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, where tensions remain high following deadly riots there last month.\n\n\"It should be well attended, but I don't know if everyone will play along and come out to vote,\" said nurse Cassandre Cazaux.\n\nMacron's decision to call the snap vote plunged the country into political turmoil and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp tumbled during the campaign, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war.\"\n\nbur-as/rox", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8202374690", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "06:51:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T06:51:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T06:39:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.geo.tv/latest/551797-far-right-eyes-landmark-win-as-france-votes-in-high-stakes-snap-elections", "title": "Far-right eyes landmark win as France votes in high-stakes snap elections", "body": "French people are set to vote in snap parliamentary elections today (Sunday) potentially leading to the far-right National Rally (RN) party, led by Marine Le Pen, taking power for the first time.\n\nThis is because there has been a significant surge in support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic party with Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, AFP reported.\n\nThe first round of elections in mainland France begins at 8:00am and ends 12 hours later, with projections predicting the results. Overseas voters cast ballots earlier, with 49 million French eligible to vote, including those in France's overseas territories.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round, a week later, on July 7.\n\nMost polls show that RN is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35% and 37% of the vote, against 27.5-29% for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20%-21% for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, its party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk {"uri": "8202549777", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "09:27:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T09:27:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T09:26:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.fox28spokane.com/france-votes-in-pivotal-snap-polls-as-far-right-eyes-power/", "title": "France votes in pivotal snap polls as far right eyes power | FOX 28 Spokane", "body": "French people voted on Sunday in the first round of high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nThe vote could put the far-right in power in France for the first time since the Nazi occupation in World War II.\n\nPolling stations opened across mainland France at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and will close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories that span the globe cast ballots earlier in the weekend. Some 49 million people are eligible to vote.\n\n\"These are not easy elections, the results are very uncertain, and the repercussions could be serious for society\", said Julien Martin, a 38-year-old architect in the southwestern city of Bordeaux.\n\nVoters lined up to cast their ballots in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, where tensions remain high following last month's deadly riots.\n\nThe vote is \"decisive\", said Cassandre Cazaux, a nurse.\n\n\"It should be well attended, but I don't know if everyone will play along and come out to vote,\" Cazaux added.\n\nBy midday local time, turnout in the archipelago, which is located between Australia and Fiji, stood at 32.4 percent, compared to 13.06 percent recorded during the 2022 legislative polls.\n\nFormer president Nicolas Sarkozy, Greens party leader Marine Tondelier and former prime minister and Macron ally Edouard Philippe were among the first high-profile politicians to vote.\n\nPhilippe, the mayor of Le Havre in northern France who has made little effort to hide his ambitions for the presidency, was seen smiling and chatting to locals on Sunday morning.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round on July 7.\n\nMost polls show the RN on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nFinal opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nMany analysts say that France is facing a hung Assembly, which could lead to deadlock and political instability.\n\n- 'Fight against hatred' -\n\nMacron's decision to call the snap vote after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, more than 100,000 joined an LGBTQ Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\n- Spike in hate speech -\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nHe apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp has collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off.\n\nThe party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war\".\n\nbur-as/cw\n\nFOX28 Spokane\u00a9", "source": {"uri": "fox28spokane.com", Some 49 million French are eligible to vote.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round, a week later, on July 7.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nMost polls show that National Rally is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, RN party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nOn Monday, Macron plans to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told Agence France-Presse.\n\nFrance is heading for a year of political chaos and confusion with a hung Assembly, said Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at Eurasia Group, a risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Rahman said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nCalls to mobilize\n\nMacron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilize against the far right.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, thousands of people joined an LGBT Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far-right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet. {"uri": "2024-06-406528762", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "12:25:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T12:25:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T11:49:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/france-votes-in-crucial-polls-as-far-right-eyes-power/article_7b107c00-cc6b-57c9-87d9-dd523c06e104.html", "title": "France votes in crucial polls as far right eyes power", "body": "Macron's decision to call the vote plunged France into political turmoil and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy\n\nFrench people voted on Sunday in the first round of high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could alter France's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the nation by calling snap polls after the far-right National Rally (RN) party's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic party has surged despite Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nThe two-round vote could put the far-right in power in France for the first time since the Nazi occupation in World War II.\n\nPolling stations opened across mainland France at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and will close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nMany voters said they were concerned about the future.\n\n\"I don't recognise my country anymore,\" Roxane Lebrun, 40, said in the southwestern city of Bordeaux.\n\n\"We have to keep fighting for what we believe in and what we want for France.\"\n\nJulien Martin, a 38-year-old architect, added: \"These are not easy elections, the results are very uncertain, and the repercussions could be serious for society.\"\n\nMacron and his wife Brigitte cast their ballots in Le Touquet in northern France.\n\nOn Monday, the French president plans to convene a government meeting to decide the next course of action, sources have told AFP.\n\nMost polls show the RN party on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house -- although it remains unclear if it will secure an outright majority.\n\nFinal opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote -- against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance, and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nMany analysts say that France is facing a hung Assembly, which could lead to deadlock and political instability.\n\n- 'Fight against hatred' -\n\nAs of noon, turnout in mainland France stood at 25.90 percent, an increase from the 18.43 percent recorded in legislative elections in 2022.\n\nThe shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round on July 7.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories had cast ballots earlier in the weekend.\n\nElectors lined up to cast ballots in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, where tensions remain high following deadly riots there last month.\n\n\"It should be well attended, but I don't know if everyone will play along and come out to vote,\" said nurse Cassandre Cazaux.\n\nFormer president Nicolas Sarkozy, Greens party leader Marine Tondelier and former prime minister and Macron ally Edouard Philippe were among the first high-profile politicians to vote.\n\nPhilippe, the mayor of Le Havre in northern France who has made little effort to hide his ambitions for the presidency, was seen smiling and chatting to locals.\n\nMacron's decision to call the snap vote plunged the country into political turmoil and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nMore than 100,000 joined an LGBTQ Pride march in Paris on Saturday, with some carrying placards targeting the far right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\n- Spike in hate speech -\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nHe apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp appears to have collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off.\n\nThe party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\nbur-as/rox\n\nMore from this section\n\nHitPaw Voice Changer V1.9.0 Updates Feature Latest AI Voice Technology Leading the Sound Revolution\n\nNew Orleans to Host The 18th Annual Edition of Its Roller Derby Themed RUNNING OF {"uri": "8202184764", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "02:31:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T02:31:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T02:31:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.tbsnews.net/worldbiz/europe/france-vote-election-could-put-far-right-government-887806", "title": "France to vote in election that could put far right in government", "body": "French voters cast their ballots on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls open at 0600 GMT, closing at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, and at 1800 GMT in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.", "source": {"uri": "tbsnews.net", "dataType": "news", "title": Power - UrduPoint", "body": "Paris, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 30th Jun, 2024) French voters turned out in large numbers on Sunday for the first round of high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could alter France's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the nation by calling snap polls after the far-right National Rally (RN) party's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month.\n\nPresented with a crucial choice about France's future, many said they could not stay home, while political observers pointed to the highest voter turnout in decades.\n\n\"I don't recognise my country anymore,\" she said. \"We have to keep fighting for what we believe in and what we want for France.\"\n\nJulien Martin, a 38-year-old architect, added: \"These are not easy elections, the results are very uncertain, and the repercussions could be serious for society.\"\n\n\"This is the highest level since the 1981 legislative elections,\" Mathieu Gallard, research director at the Ipsos polling institute, said on X (formerly Twitter).\n\nAccording to most polls, the RN party is on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if it will secure an outright majority.\n\n\"The higher the turnout, the more candidates qualify,\" he said on X.\n\nHe said that the left-wing alliance and Macron's centrist camp would be able \"to make deals to withdraw worst-placed candidates and allow the others a free run against the far right candidate\" in the second round of voting.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\n\"It should be well attended, but I don't know if everyone will play along and come out to vote,\" said nurse Cassandre Cazaux.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp tumbled during the campaign, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the {"uri": "2024-06-406419084", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "09:47:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T09:47:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T08:12:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/france-votes-in-pivotal-snap-polls-as-far-right-eyes-power/article_7b107c00-cc6b-57c9-87d9-dd523c06e104.html", "title": "France votes in pivotal snap polls as far right eyes power", "body": "Gendarmerie officers in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia secure the area outside a school where people are voting in the first round of crunch legislative elections\n\nFrench people voted on Sunday in the first round of high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nThe vote could put the far-right in power in France for the first time since the Nazi occupation in World War II.\n\nPolling stations opened across mainland France at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and will close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories that span the globe cast ballots earlier in the weekend. Some 49 million people are eligible to vote.\n\n\"These are not easy elections, the results are very uncertain, and the repercussions could be serious for society\", said Julien Martin, a 38-year-old architect in the southwestern city of Bordeaux.\n\nVoters lined up to cast their ballots in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, where tensions remain high following last month's deadly riots.\n\nThe vote is \"decisive\", said Cassandre Cazaux, a nurse.\n\n\"It should be well attended, but I don't know if everyone will play along and come out to vote,\" Cazaux added.\n\nBy midday local time, turnout in the archipelago, which is located between Australia and Fiji, stood at 32.4 percent, compared to 13.06 percent recorded during the 2022 legislative polls.\n\nFormer president Nicolas Sarkozy, Greens party leader Marine Tondelier and former prime minister and Macron ally Edouard Philippe were among the first high-profile politicians to vote.\n\nPhilippe, the mayor of Le Havre in northern France who has made little effort to hide his ambitions for the presidency, was seen smiling and chatting to locals on Sunday morning.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round on July 7.\n\nMost polls show the RN on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nFinal opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nMany analysts say that France is facing a hung Assembly, which could lead to deadlock and political instability.\n\n- 'Fight against hatred' -\n\nMacron's decision to call the snap vote after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, more than 100,000 joined an LGBTQ Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\n- Spike in hate speech -\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nHe apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp has collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off.\n\nThe party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war\".\n\nbur-as/cw\n\nMore from this section\n\nCelebrating the Success of The First Luvme Hair Workshop\n\nAlec Baldwin's case on track for trial in July as judge denies request to dismiss\n\nEnergyCAP Named Market Leader in the Summer 2024 Energy Management Software Customer "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.thenationalnews.com/news/europe/2024/06/30/voting-begins-in-french-elections-as-far-right-eyes-historic-win/", "title": "Voting begins in French elections as far-right eyes historic win", "body": "Voting has begun in the French parliamentary elections, which could result in the first far-right government since the Second World War.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron called a surprise snap ballot after his centrist alliance was crushed by Marine Le Pen's anti-immigrant and Eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party in European elections.\n\nSupport for Mr Macron's centrist camp has collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 per cent and 37 per cent of the vote, against 27.5-29 per cent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 per cent for Mr Macron's backers.\n\nThe polls first opened in France's overseas territories and at 8am local time across the country itself, with 49 million people eligible to vote.\n\nCasting his vote in Sevres, on the outskirts of Paris, 70-year-old former company director Didier Delacroix said he had voted for Macron's alliance saying \"otherwise it'll be a complete mess\".\n\nThe election is a two-stage process and the shape of the 577 seat lower house of National Assembly will only become clear after the second round of voting on July 7.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare.\n\nMost constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5 per cent of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\nVincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique, said this opens the door for the RN.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle,\" said Prof Martigny.\n\n\"So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally.\"\n\nRN party chief Jordan Bardella was seen out early casting his vote in Garches, in the suburbs of Paris.\n\nThe 28-year-old prot\u00e9g\u00e9 of Ms Le Pen, who has no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Mr Macron.\n\nThe RN was a long-time pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been as Ms Le Pen has sought to moderate the party's extremist image.\n\nIf elected, Mr Bardella said he will propose immediate legislation on to tackle what the party calls the \"flood\" of migration to the lower house of parliament within weeks.\n\nIt would abolish the policy of automatically granting French nationality at 18 to people born in France to foreign parents, providing they have lived here for at least five years since the age of 11.\n\nThe RN also has plans to toughen conditions for family reunification.\n\nAmong its other policies would be a policy of giving French citizens priority access to housing and jobs, with welfare benefits limited to French nationals.\n\nUnder RN there would be strict conditions of assimilation for those seeking citizenship including mastery of the French language and respect for French laws and customs.\n\nMr Bardella said some of the measures would be put to a nationwide referendum in 2027, following the presidential election that year, in a bid to sidestep challenges from the Constitutional Council.\n\nThe council has previously ruled that RN-proposed changes to French immigration law were unconstitutional.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be heading for an unprecedented period of turbulence as Mr Macron and Mr Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war.\n\nMs Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it {"uri": "8202462968", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "08:07:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T08:07:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T08:06:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://au.news.yahoo.com/france-votes-poll-could-hand-074639772.html", "title": "France votes in poll that could hand power to far right", "body": "Polling booths have opened in the first round of a snap parliamentary election in France that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War II - a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections in June by Marine Le Pen's National Rally.\n\nHer Eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls opened at 0600 GMT on Sunday and will close at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, with an 1800 GMT finish in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever, the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her protege, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella, would be prime minister.\n\nHer party has a high-spending economic program and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf her party does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues.\n\nFrance could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nLe Pen also has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\nOpinion polls have suggested National Rally has a comfortable lead of 33 to 36 per cent of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28 to 31 per cent and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20 to 23 per cent.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, Eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, which is rare.\n\nMost constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5 per cent of registered voters in the first round.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle,\" Martigny said.\n\n\"So then ... there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally.\"\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating National Rally, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing anti-Semitism.\n\nLe Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the {"uri": "8202541618", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "09:19:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T09:19:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T09:19:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/france-votes-in-pivotal-snap-polls-as-far-right-eyes-power/article_5cd4bce2-4388-5812-ab95-38f5a98ea55e.html", "title": "France votes in pivotal snap polls as far right eyes power", "body": "Gendarmerie officers in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia secure the area outside a school where people are voting in the first round of crunch legislative elections\n\nFrench people voted on Sunday in the first round of high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nThe vote could put the far-right in power in France for the first time since the Nazi occupation in World War II.\n\nPolling stations opened across mainland France at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and will close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories that span the globe cast ballots earlier in the weekend. Some 49 million people are eligible to vote.\n\n\"These are not easy elections, the results are very uncertain, and the repercussions could be serious for society\", said Julien Martin, a 38-year-old architect in the southwestern city of Bordeaux.\n\nVoters lined up to cast their ballots in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, where tensions remain high following last month's deadly riots.\n\nThe vote is \"decisive\", said Cassandre Cazaux, a nurse.\n\n\"It should be well attended, but I don't know if everyone will play along and come out to vote,\" Cazaux added.\n\nBy midday local time, turnout in the archipelago, which is located between Australia and Fiji, stood at 32.4 percent, compared to 13.06 percent recorded during the 2022 legislative polls.\n\nFormer president Nicolas Sarkozy, Greens party leader Marine Tondelier and former prime minister and Macron ally Edouard Philippe were among the first high-profile politicians to vote.\n\nPhilippe, the mayor of Le Havre in northern France who has made little effort to hide his ambitions for the presidency, was seen smiling and chatting to locals on Sunday morning.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round on July 7.\n\nMost polls show the RN on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nFinal opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nMany analysts say that France is facing a hung Assembly, which could lead to deadlock and political instability.\n\n- 'Fight against hatred' -\n\nMacron's decision to call the snap vote after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, more than 100,000 joined an LGBTQ Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\n- Spike in hate speech -\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nHe apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp has collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off.\n\nThe party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war\".\n\nbur-as/cw", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8202157789", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "01:45:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T01:45:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T01:44:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/world/story/france-electoon-frech-president-emmanuel-macron-2560227-2024-06-30", "title": "France to vote in historic snap polls, far-right likely to replace Macron", "body": "Macron announced early polls after his alliance was crushed in European elections\n\nFrench voters cast their ballots on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls open at 0600 GMT (11:30 am IST), closing at 1600 GMT (9:30 pm IST) in small towns and cities, and at 1800 GMT in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever, the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising Muslims and foreigners.", "source": {"uri": "indiatoday.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "India Today"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-06-406179997", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "02:31:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T02:31:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T02:31:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.timesofisrael.com/france-set-to-vote-in-fateful-election-that-could-catapult-far-right-to-power/", "title": "France set to vote in fateful election that could catapult far right to power", "body": "PARIS (Reuters) -- French voters cast their ballots on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War II, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her euroskeptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls open at 8 a.m. local time (9 a.m. Israel time), closing 10 hours later in small towns and cities, and 12 hours later in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever, the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella, would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic program and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence, with Macron -- who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 -- and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nRead More: In snap election, many French Jews reluctantly endorse far right over dreaded far left\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" -- when the president and government are from opposite political camps -- in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent worldviews competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defense.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\n'Split vote favors RN'\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead at 33-36 percent of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate center-left to the far-left, euroskeptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon, who is staunchly anti-Israel and has a history of antisemitic remarks.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer in the second round wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favors the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knows whether candidates from Macron's camp will consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatizing Muslims and foreigners.", "source": {"uri": "timesofisrael.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "timesofisrael.com"}, "authors": {"uri": "8202545307", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "09:22:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T09:22:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T09:22:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/france-votes-in-pivotal-snap-polls-as-far-right-eyes-power/article_ed0b7ed9-c3ed-524e-8e80-c29ae80eb9d4.html", "title": "France votes in pivotal snap polls as far right eyes power", "body": "Gendarmerie officers in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia secure the area outside a school where people are voting in the first round of crunch legislative elections\n\nFrench people voted on Sunday in the first round of high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nThe vote could put the far-right in power in France for the first time since the Nazi occupation in World War II.\n\nPolling stations opened across mainland France at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and will close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories that span the globe cast ballots earlier in the weekend. Some 49 million people are eligible to vote.\n\n\"These are not easy elections, the results are very uncertain, and the repercussions could be serious for society\", said Julien Martin, a 38-year-old architect in the southwestern city of Bordeaux.\n\nVoters lined up to cast their ballots in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, where tensions remain high following last month's deadly riots.\n\nThe vote is \"decisive\", said Cassandre Cazaux, a nurse.\n\n\"It should be well attended, but I don't know if everyone will play along and come out to vote,\" Cazaux added.\n\nBy midday local time, turnout in the archipelago, which is located between Australia and Fiji, stood at 32.4 percent, compared to 13.06 percent recorded during the 2022 legislative polls.\n\nFormer president Nicolas Sarkozy, Greens party leader Marine Tondelier and former prime minister and Macron ally Edouard Philippe were among the first high-profile politicians to vote.\n\nPhilippe, the mayor of Le Havre in northern France who has made little effort to hide his ambitions for the presidency, was seen smiling and chatting to locals on Sunday morning.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round on July 7.\n\nMost polls show the RN on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nFinal opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nMany analysts say that France is facing a hung Assembly, which could lead to deadlock and political instability.\n\nMore from this section Police: Rider killed in Milford motorcycle crash Nyack School Superintendent Susan Yom to step down at end of June Jan. 6 defendants from CT could get lighter sentences after Supreme Court ruling - 'Fight against hatred' -\n\nMacron's decision to call the snap vote after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nWielding mops and buckets, several activists of the Femen feminist collective dressed as cleaners on Saturday demonstrated bare-breasted at the Trocadero in Paris, chanting slogans against the extreme right.\n\nSeparately, more than 100,000 joined an LGBTQ Pride march in Paris, with some carrying placards targeting the far right.\n\n\"I think it's even more important right now to fight against hatred in general, in all its forms,\" said 19-year-old student Themis Hallin-Mallet.\n\n- Spike in hate speech -\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.\n\nMacron has deplored \"racism or anti-Semitism\".\n\nHe apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nSupport for Macron's centrist camp has collapsed, while left-wing parties put their bickering aside to form the New Popular Front, in a nod to an alliance founded in 1936 to combat fascism.\n\nAnalysts say Le Pen's years-long efforts to clean up the image of a party co-founded by a former Waffen SS member have been paying off.\n\nThe party has promised to bolster purchasing power, curb immigration and boost law and order.\n\nA defiant Macron has stood by his decision to call the elections, while warning voters that a win by the far right or hard left could spark a \"civil war\".\n\nbur-as/cw", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8202497434", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "08:40:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T08:40:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T08:39:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/france-begins-voting-in-election-that-could-hand-power-to-far-right/2154016/", "title": "France begins voting in election that could hand power to far right", "body": "However the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nAt a voting station in Sevres, on the outskirts of Paris, 70-year-old former company director Didier Delacroix said he had voted for Macron's alliance.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising Muslims and foreigners.\n\n(Additional reporting by Paris bureauWriting by Estelle ShirbonEditing by Frances Kerry and Gareth {"uri": "2024-06-406139267", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "00:16:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T00:16:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-29T20:04:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-06-29/france-to-vote-in-election-that-could-put-far-right-in-government", "title": "France to Vote in Election That Could Put Far Right in Government", "body": "A woman walks past election boards with a campaign poster of French far-right Rassemblement National (National Rally - RN) party with the faces of RN leader Marine Le Pen and RN President Jordan Bardella on the eve of the first round of the early French parliamentary elections, in Henin-Beaumont, France, June 29, 2024. The slogan reads \"Bardella Prime Minister\". REUTERS/Yves Herman\n\nPARIS (Reuters) - French voters cast their ballots on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls open at 0600 GMT, closing at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, and at 1800 GMT in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\n'SPLIT VOTE FAVOURS RN'\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising Muslims and foreigners.\n\n(Additional reporting by Paris bureau; Writing by Estelle Shirbon; Editing by Frances Kerry)",
