{"uri": "8202601719", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "10:14:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T10:14:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T10:13:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.khaleejtimes.com/world/europe/france-votes-in-pivotal-snap-polls-as-far-right-eyes-power", "title": "France votes in pivotal snap polls as far right eyes power", "body": "Francois Hollande, former French president and candidate for the left-wing political alliance called Nouveau Front Populaire (New Popular Front - NFP), prepares to cast his ballot to vote in the first round of the early French parliamentary elections at a polling station in Tulle, France, on Sunday. -- Reuters\n\nFrench people voted on Sunday in the first round of high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nWith Russia's war against Ukraine in its third year and energy and food prices much higher, support for the anti-immigration and eurosceptic National Rally (RN) party has surged despite President Emmanuel Macron's pledges to prevent its ascent.\n\nThe vote could put the far-right in power in France for the first time since the Nazi occupation in World War II.\n\nPolling stations opened across mainland France at 8:00 am (0600 GMT) and will close 12 hours later, immediately followed by projections that usually predict the result with a degree of accuracy.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories that span the globe cast ballots earlier in the weekend. Some 49 million people are eligible to vote.\n\n\"These are not easy elections, the results are very uncertain, and the repercussions could be serious for society\", said Julien Martin, a 38-year-old architect in the southwestern city of Bordeaux.\n\nVoters lined up to cast their ballots in France's Pacific territory of New Caledonia, where tensions remain high following last month's deadly riots.\n\nThe vote is \"decisive\", said Cassandre Cazaux, a nurse.\n\n\"It should be well attended, but I don't know if everyone will play along and come out to vote,\" Cazaux added.\n\nBy midday local time, turnout in the archipelago, which is located between Australia and Fiji, stood at 32.4 percent, compared to 13.06 percent recorded during the 2022 legislative polls.\n\nFormer president Nicolas Sarkozy, Greens party leader Marine Tondelier and former prime minister and Macron ally Edouard Philippe were among the first high-profile politicians to vote.\n\nPhilippe, the mayor of Le Havre in northern France who has made little effort to hide his ambitions for the presidency, was seen smiling and chatting to locals on Sunday morning.\n\nElections for the 577 seats in the National Assembly are a two-round process. The shape of the new parliament will become clear after the second round on July 7.\n\nMost polls show the RN on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house, although it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nFinal opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote, against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a tense \"cohabitation\" with Macron.\n\nMany analysts say that France is facing a hung Assembly, which could lead to deadlock and political instability.\n\nMacron's decision to call the snap vote after the RN's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 percent, according to figures released on Friday.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.", "source": {"uri": "khaleejtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Khaleej times"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-406157600", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "01:19:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T01:19:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T00:04:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.aol.com/france-vote-election-could-put-000400070.html", "title": "France to vote in election that could put far right in government", "body": "France to vote in election that could put far right in government\n\nJohnny Cotton\n\nJune 30, 2024 at 2:04 AM\n\nBy Johnny Cotton\n\nPARIS (Reuters) - French voters cast their ballots on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls open at 0600 GMT, closing at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, and at 1800 GMT in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\n'SPLIT VOTE FAVOURS RN'\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising Muslims and foreigners.\n\n(Additional reporting by Paris bureau; Writing by Estelle Shirbon; Editing by Frances Kerry)", {"uri": "8202725454", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "12:10:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T12:10:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T12:10:21Z", "dataType": "news", UrduPoint", "body": "Paris, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 30th Jun, 2024) French people voted on Sunday in the first round of high-stakes snap parliamentary elections which could alter France's trajectory and see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen take power in a historic first.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the nation by calling snap polls after the far-right National Rally (RN) party's strong showing in European Parliament elections this month.\n\nMany voters said they were concerned about the future.\n\n\"I don't recognise my country anymore,\" Roxane Lebrun, 40, said in the southwestern city of Bordeaux.\n\nJulien Martin, a 38-year-old architect, added: \"These are not easy elections, the results are very uncertain, and the repercussions could be serious for society.\"\n\nMacron and his wife Brigitte cast their ballots in Le Touquet in northern France.\n\nOn Monday, the French president plans to convene a government meeting to decide the next course of action, sources have told AFP.\n\nMost polls show the RN party on course to win the largest number of seats in the National Assembly, parliament's lower house -- although it remains unclear if it will secure an outright majority.\n\nFinal opinion polls have given the RN between 35 percent and 37 percent of the vote -- against 27.5-29 percent for the left-wing New Popular Front alliance, and 20-21 percent for Macron's centrist camp.\n\nIf the RN obtains an absolute majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege with no governing experience, could become prime minister in a {"uri": "8202535008", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "09:13:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T09:13:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T09:13:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.arnnewscentre.ae/news/international/france-votes-in-election-that-could-hand-power-to-far-right/", "title": "France votes in election that could hand power to far right", "body": "French voters began voting on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a long-time pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls opened at 0600 GMT and will close at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, with an 1800 GMT finish in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide {"uri": "8202195444", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "02:50:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T02:50:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T02:49:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/news/2024/0630/1457350-france-general-election/", "title": "France to vote in election as far right eyes historic win", "body": "French voters are due to cast their ballots in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far right government since World War II, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron shocked the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was defeated in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN).\n\nHer eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls open at 7am Irish time, closing at 5pm Irish time in small towns and cities, and at 7 pm Irish time in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever, the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on 7 July.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" Ms Le Pen said in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister.\n\nMs Le Pen's party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence, with Mr Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Mr Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nMr Bardella has already indicated he will challenge Mr Macron on global issues.\n\nFrance could change from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Mr Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war.\n\nMs Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party has said it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\nSplit vote\n\nOpinion polls suggest the RN has a comfortable lead of 33 - 36% of the popular vote, with the left-wing coalition of the New Popular Front in second place on 28- 31% and Mr Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20 - 23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by another of Mr Macron's opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique Vincent Martigny said.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare.\n\nMost constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round.\n\nThe top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation, you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" Mr Martigny said.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMr Martigny said no one knew whether candidates from Mr Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nMs Le Pen and Mr Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism.\n\nMs Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics said the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising others.", "source": {"uri": "rte.ie", "https://img.rasset.ie/00208245-1600.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9692876", "eventUri": "eng-9692876", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-07", "textStart": 981, "textEnd": 987}], "sentiment": 0.08235294117647052, "wgt": 178, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-406337503", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "07:49:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T07:49:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T07:10:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/french-elections-why-significant-020326635.html", "title": "French elections: How do they work and why are they so significant?", "body": "Emmanuel Macron's decision to call two rounds of elections on 30 June and 7 July is seen by rivals and allies as a reckless gamble that is about to hand political power to the far right.\n\nHis aim was to regain control of French politics, but that's not what the opinion polls say will happen.\n\nWhy is France holding elections?\n\nMr Macron had no need to call National Assembly elections for another three years.\n\nBut an hour after his Renew alliance was trounced in European elections by the far-right National Rally party of Jordan Bardella and Marine Le Pen on 9 June, the French president went on TV to say he couldn't act as if nothing had happened.\n\nHis party came third and he said it was time for France's people and politicians \"who do not recognise themselves in the extremist fever\" to build a new coalition. It was, he said later, the \"most responsible solution\".\n\nWhat was Macron thinking?\n\nApparently Mr Macron had been thinking about calling an election for months, but it came out of the blue even for his closest colleagues.\n\nFrance is on the cusp of a massive event, with the Paris Olympics running from 26 July to 11 August. It has now had a lightning-fast election campaign as well.\n\nMr Macron clearly wanted to break a logjam, after his failure to secure an absolute majority in the National Assembly in June 2022. Passing laws has become a real headache - he had to force through pension reforms without a vote while tougher immigration rules required National Rally support.\n\n\"France needs a clear majority if it is to act in serenity and harmony,\" Mr Macron argues. And yet he has left French politics and his own party in turmoil.\n\nHis centrist Ensemble alliance of Renaissance, Horizons and MoDem is languishing in the polls, behind a swiftly formed left-wing New Popular Front, made up of Socialists, Greens, Communists and the far-left France Unbowed (LFI).\n\n\"He killed off the presidential majority,\" said Horizons leader and ex-Prime Minister Edouard Philippe.\n\n\"This decision has created everywhere in our country, in the French people, worry, incomprehension, sometimes anger,\" says Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire.\n\nWhy are these elections so significant?\n\nFor the first time in France, National Rally could win power, despite widespread appeals to voters to steer clear of extremes.\n\nRN is led by 28-year-old Jordan Bardella and in parliament by Marine Le Pen, who has fought for the presidency three times and lost each time.\n\nBut each time she won more votes. Now the polls says her party could become the biggest in France, falling short of an absolute majority.\n\nMs Le Pen also has an eye on the next presidential election in three years' time.\n\nHow do French elections work?\n\nThere are 577 seats in the National Assembly, including 13 overseas districts and 11 constituencies that represent French expats abroad. For an absolute majority a party needs 289.\n\nThe Macron alliance had only 250 seats in the outgoing Assembly and had to build support from other parties every time to pass a law.\n\nThe first round eliminates all candidates who fail to win the support of 12.5% of locally registered voters.\n\nAnyone who scores more than 50% of the vote with a turnout of at least a quarter of the local electorate wins automatically. That normally happens only in a handful of constituencies, but the RN believes this time it could win dozens.\n\nThe second round is a series of run-offs fought either by two, three or sometimes four candidates.\n\nBecause turnout is expected to be high, Ipsos pollster Brice Teinturier estimates at least 250 seats could become three-way races next Sunday.\n\nSome candidates may drop out before 7 July to give an ally a better chance of stopping a rival from winning, for example from the far right.\n\nWhat will happen?\n\nThe two-round system means nothing is certain, but political expert J\u00e9r\u00f4me Jaffr\u00e9 says there is a real risk for the Macron camp that many of their MPs will either not qualify at all for the run-offs or scraping through in third place.\n\nRN have 88 seats in the outgoing parliament, but polls suggest they could win 220 to 260.\n\nUntil now voters have traditionally used \"le vote utile\" - tactical voting - to form a \"barrage\" and keep the far right out.\n\nBut that barrage is this time more likely to benefit the left than Mr Macron's Ensemble. And many voters in the centre might prefer RN over the Popular Front, because of the dominance of Jean-Luc M\u00e9lenchon's far-left France Unbowed.\n\nWhat if Macron's party loses?\n\nWhoever wins, Mr Macron has said he will not resign as president.\n\nIf his party loses, and National Rally wins, then the question is whether RN can win an absolute majority of 289 seats, or a relative majority similar to that held since 2022 by the Macron camp.\n\nAn RN victory could open the door to almost three years of \"cohabitation\", or power-sharing, when the president of one party heads the state and another party runs the government.\n\nIt's happened before, with domestic policy in the hands of the prime minister and foreign and defence policy in the hands of the president.\n\nUnder the constitution it is Mr Macron who decides who leads the next government. And Mr Bardella says he will not become prime minister if RN doesn't secure that absolute majority: \"I don't want to be the president's assistant.\"\n\nA relative majority, he said, would leave him unable to act: \"I'm not going to sell the French people measures or actions that I couldn't follow through.\"\n\nBut Mr Macron does have to reflect the make-up of the new Assembly, so if National Rally are the predominant party he could find it hard to choose someone else.\n\nParty campaign posters proclaim Mr Bardella as prime minister. He has a big presence on TikTok but his biggest job has been as a member of the European Parliament since 2019.\n\nHas cohabitation happened in France before?\n\nNot for more than 20 years, as parliamentary elections now come hard on the heels of presidential votes, and voting preferences do not change much within that time.\n\nThere have been three periods of cohabitation in the past:\n\n1997-2002 Socialist Lionel Jospin was prime minister under centre-right President Jacques Chirac\n\n1993-95 Centre-right Prime Minister Edouard Balladour worked with Socialist President Fran\u00e7ois Mitterrand during his second term\n\n1986-88 Jacques Chirac was prime minister under President Fran\u00e7ois Mitterrand\n\nBut nothing has really prepared France for the kind of cohabitation that could occur after 7 July.\n\nIs National Rally still far-right?\n\nFor years Marine Le Pen has sought to \"de-diabolise\" or detoxify her party from the antisemitic and extremist roots of her father, Jean-Marie Le Pen, and his fellow founders of the National Front, which she renamed as National Rally.\n\nMuch of its focus now is on the cost-of-living crisis, but many of its strict anti-immigration policies remain and a ruling this year by the Council of State, France's highest court for administration, confirmed it could be considered \"extreme right\".\n\nFrance football captain Kylian Mbapp\u00e9 has warned his compatriots \"the extremes are at the gates of power\", prompting Mr Bardella to hit back at multimillionaire sports figures \"giving lessons to people struggling to make ends meet\".\n\nMr Bardella wants to ban French dual nationals from sensitive strategic posts, calling them \"half-nationals\". He also wants to limit social welfare for immigrants and get rid of the automatic right to French citizenship for children with foreign-born parents.\n\nBut a planned ban on wearing headscarves in public is for now not a priority.\n\nAnti-Nato and anti-EU policies have also been softened and National Rally's close ties with Vladimir Putin's Russia have been quietly dropped.\n\nLeaving the EU has not been on the agenda since 2022. Instead, Mr Bardella focuses on cutting VAT (sales tax) on energy and a list of 100 essential goods and repealing the Macron pension reforms in a matter of months.\n\nWhat does the left promise?\n\nThe New Popular Front is an unlikely alliance of Socialists, Greens, Communists and France Unbowed.\n\nThey have promised to scrap the Macron pension and immigration reforms and their platform is otherwise based on the idea that \"it's either the far right, or us\".\n\nPresident Macron has attacked the group as being \"totally immigrationist\" and allowing people to change gender at their town hall, an accusation that has prompted allegations of transphobia.\n\nThe Popular Front has promised to fight antisemitism, even though it includes candidates who have been accused of making antisemitic remarks.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [{"uri": "paul_kirby@yahoo.com", "name": "Paul Kirby", "type": "author", "isAgency": {"uri": "8202540817", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "09:18:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T09:18:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T09:18:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13584681/France-heads-polls-Nicolas-Sarkozy-wife-cast-vote-round-snap-parliamentary-elections-Marine-Le-Pens-far-right-party-form-government.html", "title": "Nicolas Sarkozy and his wife cast vote in first round of snap election", "body": "The former French president and his wife arrived in France on Sunday to vote in the first round of snap parliamentary elections in Paris.\n\nNicolas Sarkozy and his wife Carla Bruni-Sarkozy were pictured preparing to vote amid the country's most polarising ballot in decades which could see the anti-immigrant and eurosceptic party of Marine Le Pen sweep to power in a historic first.\n\nDonning chic black suits and shades, the couple arrived at the Paris polling station holding hands before meeting with other voters and staff inside.\n\nPolls opened at 6am and will close at 4pm in small towns and cities, with a 6pm finish in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nVoters in France's overseas territories cast their ballots earlier this weekend - with some 49million people eligible to vote in the historic snap election.\n\nFrench former president Nicolas Sarkozy (L) and his wife Carla Bruni-Sarkozy ( R) arrive to vote for the first round of parliamentary elections in Paris, on June 30, 2024\n\nA divided France is voting in high-stakes parliamentary elections that could see the anti-immigrant and eurosceptic party of Marine Le Pen sweep to power in a historic first\n\nNicolas Sarkozy pictured inside the Paris polling station as the first day of voting commences\n\nThe election has been shaping up as a showdown between the right-wing National Rally (RN) and the left-wing New Popular Front (NFP), which is dominated by the hard-left France Unbowed.\n\nWhile polls suggest support for Le Pen's RN has strengthened in recent days, the outcome of the two-round election, called three weeks ago by French president Emmanuel Macron, remains uncertain.\n\nOne poll carried out by Les Echos newspaper suggested the RN was on track to scoop 37 per cent of the national vote - up to two points from more than a week ago.\n\nAnother poll carried out by BFM TV predicted the far-right party could win between 260 and 295 seats out of the 577 up for grabs in the National Assembly.\n\nPolls suggest the left-wing NFP could net 28 per cent of the vote, while Macron's centrist bloc follows behind at 20 per cent.\n\nOfficial campaigning for the first-round vote ended at midnight on Friday, and following Sunday's much-anticipated vote, campaigning efforts will resume on Monday for another five days before voters are called back to the polls for a final second-round ballot on July 7.\n\n'We are going to win an absolute majority,' said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister.\n\nHer party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nDonning chic black suits and shades, the couple arrived at the Paris polling station holding hands before meeting with other voters and staff inside\n\nThe former French president pictured with his ballot in hand\n\nSarkozy greeted other voters and staff members at the polling station\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues and unveiled his party's manifesto in a press conference on June 24.\n\nHe declared the RN would demand a huge cut of between \u20ac2 billion and \u20ac3 billion in France's contributions to Europe - part of a wider plan to implement what he called 'realistic, credible' economic policies as France battles spiralling national debt.\n\nFrance could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war.\n\nLe Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\nBardella's unveiling of the RN manifesto came as Emmanuel Macron warned France faces 'civil war' if either the hard-right or hard-left scores a big win in parliamentary elections.\n\nMacron had claimed the policies of the RN and France Unbowed divided and isolated people, which would ultimately lead to conflict between different communities ahead of today's first round of voting.\n\nSpeaking on the Generation Do It Yourself podcast, the French president said: 'I think that the solutions given by the far right are out of the question, because it is categorising people in terms of their religion or origins and that is why it leads to division and to civil war'.\n\nLeaders of both left and right condemned the president's remarks.\n\nFrench president Emmanuel Macron was slammed for using a 'strategy of fear' after he warned a 'civil war' could be sparked if a populist or hard-left party wins the snap election\n\nFar-right National Rally party president Jordan Bardella, right, leaves with far-right leader Marine Le Pen after a press conference, Monday, June 24, 2024 in Paris\n\nEric Ciotti, the leader of the conservative Republicans, who sparked outrage among allies by personally agreeing an election pact with the RN, accused the French president of being irresponsible.\n\n'This is a strategy of fear,' he said, speaking on BFMTV-RMC.\n\nMarine Le Pen said Macron's argument was 'weak' and showed 'he thinks he's lost this election'.\n\nSpeaking about France Unbowed, he added on the podcast: 'But that one as well, there is a civil war behind that because you are solely categorising people in terms of their religious outlook or the community they belong to'.\n\nHere, Macron was referring to accusations that France Unbowed positions itself to attract Muslim voters through its critical stance on Israel's war in Gaza.\n\nFollowing the comments, Patrick Kanner, head of the {"uri": "8202297479", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "05:10:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T05:10:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T05:09:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/france-heading-polls-high-stakes-050011631.html", "title": "France heading to the polls in high-stakes snap parliamentary election", "body": "Voters in France are heading to the polls in the first round of high stakes, snap parliamentary elections that could see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen form a government in a historic first.\n\nWhile polls suggest support for Le Pen's far-right, anti-immigrant National Rally (RN) has strengthened in recent days, the outcome of the two-round election, called three weeks ago by the president, Emmanuel Macron, following the crushing defeat of his allies in the European parliamentary elections, remains highly uncertain.\n\nOne poll carried out for Les Echos newspaper suggested that the RN was on course to win 37% of the national vote, up two points from more than a week ago, while another poll carried out for BFM TV estimated the far-right party could win between 260 and 295 seats - potentially giving it an outright majority among France's 577 constituencies.\n\nRelated: Macron told 'people detest you' as far-right bids to be biggest party in France\n\nPolls suggest the New Popular Front (NFP), a broad but fragile leftwing alliance, could receive 28% of the vote while Macron's centrist bloc trails behind at 20%.\n\nOfficial campaigning for the first-round vote ended at midnight on Friday. Following Sunday's vote, campaigning will resume on Monday for another five days before voters are called back to the polls for a final, decisive second-round ballot on 7 July.\n\nMuch could change in the five days between rounds, particularly if candidates embrace tactical alliances and withdrawals in order to block the far-right from winning a majority.\n\nIn recent days candidates from the leftwing coalition and Macron's centrist alliance have scrambled to remind voters that the RN, launched in the early 1970s as the National Front, once included in its ranks former members of a Waffen-SS military unit under Nazi command during the second world war.\n\nThe party was long seen as rife with antisemitic, homophobic and racist views, and widely regarded as a danger to democracy that needed to be kept out of mainstream politics. While Marine Le Pen, Jean-Marie Le Pen's daughter, has spent much of the past decade working to soften the party's image, its core message remains one of deep hostility to immigration and the so-called Islamisation of society.\n\nThe party has vowed to drastically slash immigration and bar dual nationals from certain state jobs, along with promises to cut taxes on energy, exempt people under the age of 30 from income tax and work towards abolishing Macron's pension reform.\n\nAhead of Sunday's first round, Le Pen urged voters to go out and vote. \"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" she wrote on social media.\n\nMost analysts suggest the most likely outcome is a polarised parliament, where consensus between the larger far-right and leftwing blocs, and a smaller number of Macron's allies would be nearly impossible, leading to political paralysis.\n\nIf the RN wins a majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege who has no governing experience, could become prime minister in a fraught cohabitation with Macron.\n\nThe result could pit the two men - who have vastly different visions of France's future - against each other. One example is France's strong support for Ukraine, championed by Macron since Russia's 2022 invasion. Bardella has said he would use his powers as prime minister to stop Macron from continuing to supply long-range weapons to Ukraine.\n\nFollowing Sunday's first-round vote, Macron is planning to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nThe president's shock decision to call parliamentary elections has sparked dissent among his allies and cast Europe's second-biggest economy into uncertainty. Even so, Macron has stood by his decision, reportedly hoping it would force voters to confront whether they were ready to allow the far-right to tighten its grip on power.\n\nIn the lead-up to Sunday's first round vote, Macron sought to hammer home this point, warning that France risks being plunged into a \"civil war\" if either of his \"extreme\" opponents win a majority.\n\nThe president has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, regardless of which party wins.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": election with far-right poised for unprecedented win", "body": "France's far-right party has high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration\n\nFrench voters began voting on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War II, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union (EU).\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's eurosceptic, anti-immigrant National Rally (RN) for the first time.\n\nPolls opened at 0600 GMT and will close at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, with an 1800 GMT finish in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected, Reuters reported.\n\nHowever, the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister.\n\nHer party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron -- who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 -- and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nHe has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide {"uri": "8202290579", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "05:01:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T05:01:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T05:01:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/jun/30/france-heading-to-the-polls-in-high-stakes-snap-parliamentary-election", "title": "France heading to the polls in high-stakes snap parliamentary election", "body": "Ballot could see Marine Le Pen's National Rally form government as polls suggest support for far-right party has strengthened\n\nVoters in France are heading to the polls in the first round of high stakes, snap parliamentary elections that could see the far-right party of Marine Le Pen form a government in a historic first.\n\nWhile polls suggest support for Le Pen's far-right, anti-immigrant National Rally (RN) has strengthened in recent days, the outcome of the two-round election, called three weeks ago by the president, Emmanuel Macron, following the crushing defeat of his allies in the European parliamentary elections, remains highly uncertain.\n\nOne poll carried out for Les Echos newspaper suggested that the RN was on course to win 37% of the national vote, up two points from more than a week ago, while another poll carried out for BFM TV estimated the far-right party could win between 260 and 295 seats - potentially giving it an outright majority among France's 577 constituencies.\n\nPolls suggest the New Popular Front (NFP), a broad but fragile leftwing alliance, could receive 28% of the vote while Macron's centrist bloc trails behind at 20%.\n\nOfficial campaigning for the first-round vote ended at midnight on Friday. Following Sunday's vote, campaigning will resume on Monday for another five days before voters are called back to the polls for a final, decisive second-round ballot on 7 July.\n\nMuch could change in the five days between rounds, particularly if candidates embrace tactical alliances and withdrawals in order to block the far-right from winning a majority.\n\nIn recent days candidates from the leftwing coalition and Macron's centrist alliance have scrambled to remind voters that the RN, launched in the early 1970s as the National Front, once included in its ranks former members of a Waffen-SS military unit under Nazi command during the second world war.\n\nThe party was long seen as rife with antisemitic, homophobic and racist views, and widely regarded as a danger to democracy that needed to be kept out of mainstream politics. While Marine Le Pen, Jean-Marie Le Pen's daughter, has spent much of the past decade working to soften the party's image, its core message remains one of deep hostility to immigration and the so-called Islamisation of society.\n\nThe party has vowed to drastically slash immigration and bar dual nationals from certain state jobs, along with promises to cut taxes on energy, exempt people under the age of 30 from income tax and work towards abolishing Macron's pension reform.\n\nAhead of Sunday's first round, Le Pen urged voters to go out and vote. \"Victory is within our grasp, so let's seize this historic opportunity and get out and vote!\" she wrote on social media.\n\nMost analysts suggest the most likely outcome is a polarised parliament, where consensus between the larger far-right and leftwing blocs, and a smaller number of Macron's allies would be nearly impossible, leading to political paralysis.\n\nIf the RN wins a majority, party chief Jordan Bardella, Le Pen's 28-year-old protege who has no governing experience, could become prime minister in a fraught cohabitation with Macron.\n\nThe result could pit the two men - who have vastly different visions of France's future - against each other. One example is France's strong support for Ukraine, championed by Macron since Russia's 2022 invasion. Bardella has said he would use his powers as prime minister to stop Macron from continuing to supply long-range weapons to Ukraine.\n\nFollowing Sunday's first-round vote, Macron is planning to convene a government meeting to decide the further course of action, government sources told AFP.\n\nThe president's shock decision to call parliamentary elections has sparked dissent among his allies and cast Europe's second-biggest economy into uncertainty. Even so, Macron has stood by his decision, reportedly hoping it would force voters to confront whether they were ready to allow the far-right to tighten its grip on power.\n\nIn the lead-up to Sunday's first round vote, Macron sought to hammer home this point, warning that France risks being plunged into a \"civil war\" if either of his \"extreme\" opponents win a majority.\n\nThe president has insisted he will serve out the remainder of his second term until 2027, regardless of which party wins.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, {"uri": "8202224479", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "03:31:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T03:31:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T03:29:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/france-to-vote-in-election-that-could-put-far-right-in-government/2153795/", "title": "France to vote in election that could put far right in government", "body": "Polls open at 0600 GMT, closing at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, and at 1800 GMT in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising Muslims and foreigners.\n\n(Additional reporting by Paris bureau; Writing by Estelle Shirbon; Editing by Frances Kerry)", {"uri": "8202815769", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "13:36:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T13:36:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T13:33:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/france-votes-in-election-that-could-hand-power-to-far-right/2154225/", "title": "France votes in election that could hand power to far right", "body": "However the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" Le Pen said in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella, would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nA woman screamed \"It's shameful, it's shameful\" as Bardella arrived to cast his vote in Garches near Paris. \"They even invited the leftists,\" he said.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\nIn H\u00e9nin-Beaumont, a town in Le Pen's constituency in northern France where she may be re-elected in the first round, 67-year-old Denis Ledieu said people were suffering due to the long-term deindustrializaton of the region.\n\n\"So if the (RN) promises them things, then why not? They want to try it out, I think,\" he said.\n\nAcross France, early turnout figures were higher than in the 2022 legislative vote, at 25.9% by midday, compared with 18.43% two years ago, the interior ministry said.\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33%-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28%-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20%-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" Martigny said.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising Muslims and foreigners.\n\n(Additional reporting by Ardee Napolitano and Janis Laizans in H\u00e9nin-Beaumont and Clotaire Achi, Macron and far-right leader Le Pen cast their votes in the country's parliamentary election\n\n:: June 30, 2024\n\n:: Macron triggered the snap elections after Le Pen's party trounced his in June European elections\n\nLe Pen and her far-right National Rally (RN) party have taken center stage in France's parliamentary electoral campaign, after the RN trounced President Emmanuel Macron's party in the early June European elections, leading him to trigger the snap vote.\n\nFrance is the closest it has been to having a far-right government since World War Two, with the anti-immigrant RN riding high in opinion polls ahead of the two-phase legislative election, whose second round is on July 7.\n\nMacron will remain president after the election, but will have to pick a prime minister from whichever party or alliance can command a majority in the National Assembly, regardless of how divergent their policies are from his own.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8202737806", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "12:22:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T12:22:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T12:21:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.businesstelegraph.co.uk/france-votes-in-snap-election-that-could-hand-power-to-the-far-right/", "title": "France votes in snap election that could hand power to the far right - Business Telegraph", "body": "Vandalized posters with images of local candidates for the European Parliament election mixed with those from the first round of the 2024 French legislative elections, seen on June 24 2024, in Val d Arry, Calvados. France will hold an early legislative election in two rounds on June 30 and July 7 2024, following President Emmanuel Macrons decision which was triggered by his party's heavy defeat to the far-right National Rally in the 2024 European Parliament election.\n\nNurphoto | Nurphoto | Getty Images\n\nFrench voters are heading to the polls on Sunday for the first round of voting in a snap parliamentary election that could see the far-right National Rally group become the biggest party in France's National Assembly, polls suggest.\n\nFrance's President Emmanuel Macron shocked the electorate and political pundits in early June when he called the ballot after his Renaissance party suffered a drubbing in European Parliament elections at the hands of National Rally, led by Jordan Bardella and veteran right-wing politician Marine Le Pen.\n\nFrench far-right Rassemblement National (RN) party President and lead MEP Jordan Bardella (R) gives his electoral card to vote at a polling station in the first round of parliamentary elections in Garches, suburb of Paris, on June 30, 2024.\n\nJulien De Rosa | Afp | Getty Images\n\nCalling the snap election, which involves two rounds of polling on Sunday and on July 7, Macron said the vote would provide \"clarification\" and that \"France needs a clear majority to act in serenity and harmony.\"\n\nAnalysts said Macron's shock move was likely based on the gamble that, even if National Rally performs well, a potentially chaotic and disordered period in power will reduce the likelihood that his rival Le Pen will assume French leadership in 2027.\n\nClose watchers of French politics also note that Macron is ultimately betting on French citizens fearing a far-right government and voting against the nationalist and anti-immigration party.\n\nBut voter polls in June have consistently put National Rally ahead in the race, predicting the party will take around 35% of the vote, ahead of the leftist New Popular Front bloc with around 25-26% of the ballot and Macron's centrist Together alliance, in third place with around 19% of the vote.\n\nEven if a hung parliament is the most likely outcome of the vote -- with no single party looking as if it can achieve an absolute majority of 289 seats in the 577-seat National Assembly -- a strong showing for National Rally will put pressure on Macron to appoint a prime minister from the party.\n\nThat new PM -- who in this scenario would likely be the 28-year-old National Rally President Jordan Bardella -- would then have a significant say over France's domestic and economic policy, while President Macron would remain in charge of foreign policy and defense.\n\nMarine Le Pen, President of the National Rally group in the National Assembly, joins Jordan Bardella, President of the National Rally (Rassemblement National), at the final rally before the upcoming European Parliament election on June 9th, held at Le D\u00f4me de Paris - Palais des Sports, on June 2, 2024.\n\nNurphoto | Nurphoto | Getty Images\n\nIn any case, such an outcome would force ideologically different (and often opposed) politicians into an uneasy and awkward \"cohabitation\" where government is likely fractious and unstable, prompting some concern among economists as to how the vote could affect the euro zone's second-largest economy.\n\n\"The market has reacted negatively to the election uncertainty, with French equities underperforming and the France-Germany 10-year yield spread widening,\" Peter Garnry, head of Strategy at Saxo Bank, said in a note Monday.\n\n\"Despite this, some views suggest the market may be overreacting, drawing parallels to Italy's experience under Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, whose initially feared policies were more pragmatic than expected,\" he noted.\n\nDeal-making\n\nPolitical analysts point out that a period of hard bargaining is likely to follow the election, as parties look to forge alliances that would enable them to achieve parliamentary majority and govern as fractiously as possible. It could be a torturous process, analysts warn.\n\n\"As with the 2022 elections, no party or bloc is likely to secure enough seats to form a majority government, although some polls give the RN an outside chance of doing so. The next government is highly likely to require some form of negotiation between different parties,\" George Dyson, senior analyst at Control Risks said in analysis Monday.\n\n\"In the event that the RN secures enough votes to come close to forming a government, it will potentially be able to secure support from dissident members of the [center-right] Republicans to secure a majority or argue that no other government is feasible.\"\n\nDyson noted that, as current polling suggests that the united left bloc will be the second largest in parliament after the RN, the next administration may also conceivably be a left-wing government that can cobble together support from the Republicans and Macron's centrist Renaissance party.\n\n\"Macron will likely push for support from centrist parties to put forwards a candidate of his choosing for prime minister, but the parties would be unlikely to provide their support as his party is projected to perform very poorly,\" Dyson said.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron looks on after delivering a speech to the Nexus Institute in the Amare theatre in The Hague on April 11, 2023 as part of a state visit to the Netherlands.\n\nLudovic Marin | AFP | Getty Images\n\nEven if a new prime minister were supported by centrist parties, the government would be \"subject to regular confidence votes and will have to engage in complex consensus-building every time it seeks to pass legislation that is even remotely divisive,\" Dyson added.\n\nA far-right government with a parliamentary majority would meanwhile find itself at odds ideologically with the president, \"who would likely use his position to undermine its policy plans,\" Dyson added. \"A similar but less dramatic situation would likely occur between a left-wing prime minister and the president.\"\n\n\"In all cases, this will result in heightened political uncertainty and instability. It will also result in backtracking and changes to announced policy plans amid repeated negotiating and consensus building, creating regulatory uncertainty for businesses,\" Dyson said.\n\nREAD {"uri": "8202101425", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "00:08:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T00:08:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T00:07:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13584123/France-vote-election-far-right-government.html", "title": "France to vote in election that could put far right in government", "body": "France holds first round of parliamentary election\n\n*\n\nAnti-immigrant, eurosceptic RN party ahead in polls\n\n*\n\nLeftist bloc in second, Macron's centrists in third\n\n*\n\nSecond round will take place on July 7\n\n*\n\nRN victory would disrupt policy towards EU, Ukraine\n\nBy Johnny Cotton\n\nPARIS, June 30 (Reuters) - French voters cast their ballots on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls open at 0600 GMT, closing at 1600 GMT in small towns and cities, and at 1800 GMT in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic programme and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" - when the president and government are from opposite political camps - in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defence.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\n'SPLIT VOTE FAVOURS RN'\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33-36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28-31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20-23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. Le Pen's father Jean-Marie Le Pen, founder and long-term leader of the RN's forerunner, had a history of overtly antisemitic comments.\n\nBut critics say the RN's courting of Jews is just a cover allowing it to deny accusations of racism while constantly stigmatising Muslims and foreigners. {"uri": "8202118394", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-30", "time": "00:38:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-30T00:38:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-30T00:37:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-france-to-vote-in-election-that-could-install-first-far-right/", "title": "France to vote in election that could install first far-right government since WWII", "body": "French voters cast their ballots on Sunday in the first round of a snap parliamentary election that could usher in the country's first far-right government since World War Two, a potential sea change at the heart of the European Union.\n\nPresident Emmanuel Macron stunned the country when he called the vote after his centrist alliance was crushed in European elections this month by Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN). Her eurosceptic, anti-immigrant party was a longtime pariah but is now closer to power than it has ever been.\n\nPolls open at 6 a.m. GMT, closing at 4 p.m. GMT in small towns and cities, and at 6 p.m. GMT in the bigger cities, when the first exit polls for the night and seat projections for the decisive second round a week later are expected.\n\nHowever the electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on July 7.\n\n\"We are going to win an absolute majority,\" said Le Pen in a newspaper interview on Wednesday, predicting that her prot\u00e9g\u00e9, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella would be prime minister. Her party has a high-spending economic program and seeks to reduce immigration.\n\nIf the RN does win an absolute majority, French diplomacy could be headed for an unprecedented period of turbulence: with Macron - who has said he will continue his presidency until the end of his term in 2027 - and Bardella jostling for the right to speak for France.\n\nFrance has had three periods of \"cohabitation\" -- when the president and government are from opposite political camps -- in its post-war history, but none with such radically divergent world views competing at the top of the state.\n\nBardella has already indicated he would challenge Macron on global issues. France could lurch from being a pillar of the EU to a thorn in its side, demanding a rebate of the French contribution to the EU budget, clashing with Brussels over European Commission jobs and reversing Macron's calls for greater EU unity and assertiveness on defense.\n\nA clear RN victory would also bring uncertainty as to where France stands on the Russia-Ukraine war. Le Pen has a history of pro-Russian sentiment and while the party now says it would help Ukraine defend itself against Russian invaders, it has also set out red lines, such as refusing to provide long-range missiles.\n\nOpinion polls have suggested the RN has a comfortable lead of 33 to 36% of the popular vote, with a hastily assembled left-wing coalition, the New Popular Front, in second place on 28 to 31% and Macron's centrist alliance in third on 20 to 23%.\n\nThe New Popular Front includes a wide range of parties, from the moderate centre-left to the hard-left, eurosceptic, anti-NATO party France Unbowed, led by one of Macron's most vitriolic opponents, Jean-Luc Melenchon.\n\nHow the poll numbers will translate into seats in the National Assembly is hard to predict because of how the election works, said Vincent Martigny, professor of political science at the University of Nice and the Ecole Polytechnique.\n\nCandidates can be elected in the first round if they win an absolute majority of votes in their constituency, but that is rare. Most constituencies will need a second round involving all candidates who received votes from at least 12.5% of registered voters in the first round. The top scorer wins.\n\n\"If you have a very high level of participation you might have a third or fourth party that is getting into the struggle. So then of course there's a risk of split voting and we know that the split vote favours the National Rally,\" said Martigny.\n\nFor decades, as the far right steadily gained popularity, voters and parties who did not support it would unite against it whenever it edged closer to national power, but that may not hold true this time.\n\nMartigny said no one knew whether candidates from Macron's camp would consider dropping out of the second round to give rivals from the left a chance of beating the RN, or the reverse.\n\nLe Pen and Bardella have sought to make their party's image more acceptable to the mainstream, for example by denouncing antisemitism. "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.straitstimes.com/world/europe/far-right-scents-power-as-tense-france-ready-for-snap-vote", "title": "Far right scents power as tense France ready for snap vote", "body": "PARIS - A divided France braced itself for high-stakes parliamentary elections that could see the anti-immigrant and eurosceptic party of Ms Marine Le Pen sweep to power in a historic first.\n\nThe candidates formally ended their frantic campaigns at midnight on June 28, with political activity banned until June 30's first round of voting.\n\nMost polls show that Ms Le Pen's far-right National Rally (RN) is on course to win the largest number of National Assembly seats, though it remains unclear if the party will secure an outright majority.\n\nA high turnout is predicted and final opinion polls have given the RN between 35 per cent and 37 per cent of the vote, against 27.5-29 per cent for the left wing New Popular Front alliance and 20-21 per cent for President Emmanuel Macron's centrist camp.\n\nThat would put France on course for political chaos and confusion with a hung parliament, said Mr Mujtaba Rahman, Europe head at the Eurasia Group risk consultancy.\n\n\"There is no precedent in recent French politics for such an impasse,\" Mr Rahman said.\n\nMr Macron's decision to call snap elections after the RN's runaway victory in European Parliament elections in June stunned friends and foes and sparked uncertainty in Europe's second-biggest economy.\n\nThe Paris stock exchange suffered its biggest monthly decline in two years in June, dropping by 6.4 per cent.\n\nIn an editorial, French daily Le Monde said it was time to mobilise against the far right.\n\n\"Yielding any power to it means nothing less than taking the risk of seeing everything that has been built and conquered over more than two and a half centuries gradually being undone,\" it said.\n\nMr Brice Teinturier, head of the Ipsos polling firm, said there were two tendancies coming out of the campaign.\n\n\"One is a dynamic of hope\" with left wing and RN supporters believing that \"there can be a change\".\n\nBut Mr Teinturier also highlighted \"the negative politicisation, the fear, the dread caused by the RN and in a part of the electorate by the France Unbowed and the coalition of the left\".\n\nMr Macron apparently hoped to catch political opponents off guard by presenting voters with a crucial choice about France's future, but observers say he might have lost his gamble.\n\nMany have pointed to a spike in hate speech, intolerance and racism during the charged campaign. A video of two RN supporters verbally assaulting a black woman has gone viral in recent days.", "source": {"uri": "straitstimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Straits Times"}, "authors": [],
